summary.long: Ezekiel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: On July 31 of my thirtieth year, while I was with the Judean exiles beside the Kebar River in Babylon, the heavens were opened and I saw visions of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This happened during the fifth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The Lord gave this message to Ezekiel son of Buzi, a priest, beside the Kebar River in the land of the Babylonians, and he felt the hand of the Lord take hold of him.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As I looked, I saw a great storm coming from the north, driving before it a huge cloud that flashed with lightning and shone with brilliant light. There was fire inside the cloud, and in the middle of the fire glowed something like gleaming amber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the center of the cloud came four living beings that looked human,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: except that each had four faces and four wings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their legs were straight, and their feet had hooves like those of a calf and shone like burnished bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under each of their four wings I could see human hands. So each of the four beings had four faces and four wings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wings of each living being touched the wings of the beings beside it. Each one moved straight forward in any direction without turning around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each had a human face in the front, the face of a lion on the right side, the face of an ox on the left side, and the face of an eagle at the back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each had two pairs of outstretched wings—one pair stretched out to touch the wings of the living beings on either side of it, and the other pair covered its body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went in whatever direction the spirit chose, and they moved straight forward in any direction without turning around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The living beings looked like bright coals of fire or brilliant torches, and lightning seemed to flash back and forth among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the living beings darted to and fro like flashes of lightning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As I looked at these beings, I saw four wheels touching the ground beside them, one wheel belonging to each.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wheels sparkled as if made of beryl. All four wheels looked alike and were made the same; each wheel had a second wheel turning crosswise within it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The beings could move in any of the four directions they faced, without turning as they moved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rims of the four wheels were tall and frightening, and they were covered with eyes all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the living beings moved, the wheels moved with them. When they flew upward, the wheels went up, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The spirit of the living beings was in the wheels. So wherever the spirit went, the wheels and the living beings also went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the beings moved, the wheels moved. When the beings stopped, the wheels stopped. When the beings flew upward, the wheels rose up, for the spirit of the living beings was in the wheels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Spread out above them was a surface like the sky, glittering like crystal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beneath this surface the wings of each living being stretched out to touch the others’ wings, and each had two wings covering its body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they flew, their wings sounded to me like waves crashing against the shore or like the voice of the Almighty or like the shouting of a mighty army. When they stopped, they let down their wings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they stood with wings lowered, a voice spoke from beyond the crystal surface above them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Above this surface was something that looked like a throne made of blue lapis lazuli. And on this throne high above was a figure whose appearance resembled a man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From what appeared to be his waist up, he looked like gleaming amber, flickering like a fire. And from his waist down, he looked like a burning flame, shining with splendor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All around him was a glowing halo, like a rainbow shining in the clouds on a rainy day. This is what the glory of the Lord looked like to me. When I saw it, I fell face down on the ground, and I heard someone’s voice speaking to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Stand up, son of man,” said the voice. “I want to speak with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Spirit came into me as he spoke, and he set me on my feet. I listened carefully to his words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man,” he said, “I am sending you to the nation of Israel, a rebellious nation that has rebelled against me. They and their ancestors have been rebelling against me to this very day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are a stubborn and hard-hearted people. But I am sending you to say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And whether they listen or refuse to listen—for remember, they are rebels—at least they will know they have had a prophet among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, do not fear them or their words. Don’t be afraid even though their threats surround you like nettles and briers and stinging scorpions. Do not be dismayed by their dark scowls, even though they are rebels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must give them my messages whether they listen or not. But they won’t listen, for they are completely rebellious!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Son of man, listen to what I say to you. Do not join them in their rebellion. Open your mouth, and eat what I give you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I looked and saw a hand reaching out to me. It held a scroll,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: which he unrolled. And I saw that both sides were covered with funeral songs, words of sorrow, and pronouncements of doom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The voice said to me, “Son of man, eat what I am giving you—eat this scroll! Then go and give its message to the people of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I opened my mouth, and he fed me the scroll.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Fill your stomach with this,” he said. And when I ate it, it tasted as sweet as honey in my mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, “Son of man, go to the people of Israel and give them my messages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am not sending you to a foreign people whose language you cannot understand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, I am not sending you to people with strange and difficult speech. If I did, they would listen!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of Israel won’t listen to you any more than they listen to me! For the whole lot of them are hard-hearted and stubborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But look, I have made you as obstinate and hard-hearted as they are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have made your forehead as hard as the hardest rock! So don’t be afraid of them or fear their angry looks, even though they are rebels.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he added, “Son of man, let all my words sink deep into your own heart first. Listen to them carefully for yourself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then go to your people in exile and say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says!’ Do this whether they listen to you or not.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit lifted me up, and I heard a loud rumbling sound behind me. (May the glory of the Lord be praised in his place!)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was the sound of the wings of the living beings as they brushed against each other and the rumbling of their wheels beneath them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Spirit lifted me up and took me away. I went in bitterness and turmoil, but the Lord’s hold on me was strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I came to the colony of Judean exiles in Tel-abib, beside the Kebar River. I was overwhelmed and sat among them for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After seven days the Lord gave me a message. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, I have appointed you as a watchman for Israel. Whenever you receive a message from me, warn people immediately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I warn the wicked, saying, ‘You are under the penalty of death,’ but you fail to deliver the warning, they will die in their sins. And I will hold you responsible for their deaths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you warn them and they refuse to repent and keep on sinning, they will die in their sins. But you will have saved yourself because you obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If righteous people turn away from their righteous behavior and ignore the obstacles I put in their way, they will die. And if you do not warn them, they will die in their sins. None of their righteous acts will be remembered, and I will hold you responsible for their deaths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you warn righteous people not to sin and they listen to you and do not sin, they will live, and you will have saved yourself, too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord took hold of me and said, “Get up and go out into the valley, and I will speak to you there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I got up and went, and there I saw the glory of the Lord, just as I had seen in my first vision by the Kebar River. And I fell face down on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit came into me and set me on my feet. He spoke to me and said, “Go to your house and shut yourself in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There, son of man, you will be tied with ropes so you cannot go out among the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will make your tongue stick to the roof of your mouth so that you will be speechless and unable to rebuke them, for they are rebels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when I give you a message, I will loosen your tongue and let you speak. Then you will say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says!’ Those who choose to listen will listen, but those who refuse will refuse, for they are rebels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, son of man, take a large clay brick and set it down in front of you. Then draw a map of the city of Jerusalem on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Show the city under siege. Build a wall around it so no one can escape. Set up the enemy camp, and surround the city with siege ramps and battering rams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take an iron griddle and place it between you and the city. Turn toward the city and demonstrate how harsh the siege will be against Jerusalem. This will be a warning to the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now lie on your left side and place the sins of Israel on yourself. You are to bear their sins for the number of days you lie there on your side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am requiring you to bear Israel’s sins for 390 days—one day for each year of their sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that, turn over and lie on your right side for 40 days—one day for each year of Judah’s sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Meanwhile, keep staring at the siege of Jerusalem. Lie there with your arm bared and prophesy her destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will tie you up with ropes so you won’t be able to turn from side to side until the days of your siege have been completed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now go and get some wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and emmer wheat, and mix them together in a storage jar. Use them to make bread for yourself during the 390 days you will be lying on your side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ration this out to yourself, eight ounces of food for each day, and eat it at set times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then measure out a jar of water for each day, and drink it at set times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Prepare and eat this food as you would barley cakes. While all the people are watching, bake it over a fire using dried human dung as fuel and then eat the bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said, “This is how Israel will eat defiled bread in the Gentile lands to which I will banish them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I said, “O Sovereign Lord, must I be defiled by using human dung? For I have never been defiled before. From the time I was a child until now I have never eaten any animal that died of sickness or was killed by other animals. I have never eaten any meat forbidden by the law.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All right,” the Lord said. “You may bake your bread with cow dung instead of human dung.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told me, “Son of man, I will make food very scarce in Jerusalem. It will be weighed out with great care and eaten fearfully. The water will be rationed out drop by drop, and the people will drink it with dismay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lacking food and water, people will look at one another in terror, and they will waste away under their punishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, take a sharp sword and use it as a razor to shave your head and beard. Use a scale to weigh the hair into three equal parts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Place a third of it at the center of your map of Jerusalem. After acting out the siege, burn it there. Scatter another third across your map and chop it with a sword. Scatter the last third to the wind, for I will scatter my people with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep just a bit of the hair and tie it up in your robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take some of these hairs out and throw them into the fire, burning them up. A fire will then spread from this remnant and destroy all of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: This is an illustration of what will happen to Jerusalem. I placed her at the center of the nations,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but she has rebelled against my regulations and decrees and has been even more wicked than the surrounding nations. She has refused to obey the regulations and decrees I gave her to follow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: You people have behaved worse than your neighbors and have refused to obey my decrees and regulations. You have not even lived up to the standards of the nations around you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, I myself, the Sovereign Lord, am now your enemy. I will punish you publicly while all the nations watch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of your detestable idols, I will punish you like I have never punished anyone before or ever will again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Parents will eat their own children, and children will eat their parents. I will punish you and scatter to the winds the few who survive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, I will cut you off completely. I will show you no pity at all because you have defiled my Temple with your vile images and detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A third of your people will die in the city from disease and famine. A third of them will be slaughtered by the enemy outside the city walls. And I will scatter a third to the winds, chasing them with my sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then at last my anger will be spent, and I will be satisfied. And when my fury against them has subsided, all Israel will know that I, the Lord, have spoken to them in my jealous anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So I will turn you into a ruin, a mockery in the eyes of the surrounding nations and to all who pass by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will become an object of mockery and taunting and horror. You will be a warning to all the nations around you. They will see what happens when the Lord punishes a nation in anger and rebukes it, says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will shower you with the deadly arrows of famine to destroy you. The famine will become more and more severe until every crumb of food is gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And along with the famine, wild animals will attack you and rob you of your children. Disease and war will stalk your land, and I will bring the sword of the enemy against you. I, the Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again a message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face the mountains of Israel and prophesy against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Proclaim this message from the Sovereign Lord against the mountains of Israel. This is what the Sovereign Lord says to the mountains and hills and to the ravines and valleys: I am about to bring war upon you, and I will smash your pagan shrines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All your altars will be demolished, and your places of worship will be destroyed. I will kill your people in front of your idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will lay your corpses in front of your idols and scatter your bones around your altars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wherever you live there will be desolation, and I will destroy your pagan shrines. Your altars will be demolished, your idols will be smashed, your places of worship will be torn down, and all the religious objects you have made will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The place will be littered with corpses, and you will know that I alone am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But I will let a few of my people escape destruction, and they will be scattered among the nations of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then when they are exiled among the nations, they will remember me. They will recognize how hurt I am by their unfaithful hearts and lustful eyes that long for their idols. Then at last they will hate themselves for all their detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will know that I alone am the Lord and that I was serious when I said I would bring this calamity on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Clap your hands in horror, and stamp your feet. Cry out because of all the detestable sins the people of Israel have committed. Now they are going to die from war and famine and disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Disease will strike down those who are far away in exile. War will destroy those who are nearby. And anyone who survives will be killed by famine. So at last I will spend my fury on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will know that I am the Lord when their dead lie scattered among their idols and altars on every hill and mountain and under every green tree and every great shade tree—the places where they offered sacrifices to their idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will crush them and make their cities desolate from the wilderness in the south to Riblah in the north. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, this is what the Sovereign Lord says to Israel:
“The end is here!
    Wherever you look—
east, west, north, or south—
    your land is finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No hope remains,
    for I will unleash my anger against you.
I will call you to account
    for all your detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will turn my eyes away and show no pity.
    I will repay you for all your detestable sins.
Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“This is what the Sovereign Lord says:
Disaster after disaster
    is coming your way!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The end has come.
    It has finally arrived.
    Your final doom is waiting!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O people of Israel, the day of your destruction is dawning.
    The time has come; the day of trouble is near.
Shouts of anguish will be heard on the mountains,
    not shouts of joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Soon I will pour out my fury on you
    and unleash my anger against you.
I will call you to account
    for all your detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will turn my eyes away and show no pity.
    I will repay you for all your detestable sins.
Then you will know that it is I, the Lord,
    who is striking the blow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The day of judgment is here;
    your destruction awaits!
The people’s wickedness and pride
    have blossomed to full flower.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their violence has grown into a rod
    that will beat them for their wickedness.
None of these proud and wicked people will survive.
    All their wealth and prestige will be swept away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, the time has come;
    the day is here!
Buyers should not rejoice over bargains,
    nor sellers grieve over losses,
for all of them will fall
    under my terrible anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if the merchants survive,
    they will never return to their business.
For what God has said applies to everyone—
    it will not be changed!
Not one person whose life is twisted by sin
    will ever recover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The trumpet calls Israel’s army to mobilize,
    but no one listens,
    for my fury is against them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is war outside the city
    and disease and famine within.
Those outside the city walls
    will be killed by enemy swords.
Those inside the city
    will die of famine and disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The survivors who escape to the mountains
    will moan like doves, weeping for their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their hands will hang limp,
    their knees will be weak as water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will dress themselves in burlap;
    horror and shame will cover them.
They will shave their heads
    in sorrow and remorse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They will throw their money in the streets,
    tossing it out like worthless trash.
Their silver and gold won’t save them
    on that day of the Lord’s anger.
It will neither satisfy nor feed them,
    for their greed can only trip them up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They were proud of their beautiful jewelry
    and used it to make detestable idols and vile images.
Therefore, I will make all their wealth
    disgusting to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will give it as plunder to foreigners,
    to the most wicked of nations,
    and they will defile it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will turn my eyes from them
    as these robbers invade and defile my treasured land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Prepare chains for my people,
    for the land is bloodied by terrible crimes.
    Jerusalem is filled with violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bring the most ruthless of nations
    to occupy their homes.
I will break down their proud fortresses
    and defile their sanctuaries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terror and trembling will overcome my people.
    They will look for peace but not find it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Calamity will follow calamity;
    rumor will follow rumor.
They will look in vain
    for a vision from the prophets.
They will receive no teaching from the priests
    and no counsel from the leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king and the prince will stand helpless,
    weeping in despair,
and the people’s hands
    will tremble with fear.
I will bring on them
    the evil they have done to others,
and they will receive the punishment
    they so richly deserve.
Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then on September 17, during the sixth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, while the leaders of Judah were in my home, the Sovereign Lord took hold of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I saw a figure that appeared to be a man. From what appeared to be his waist down, he looked like a burning flame. From the waist up he looked like gleaming amber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He reached out what seemed to be a hand and took me by the hair. Then the Spirit lifted me up into the sky and transported me to Jerusalem in a vision from God. I was taken to the north gate of the inner courtyard of the Temple, where there is a large idol that has made the Lord very jealous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly, the glory of the God of Israel was there, just as I had seen it before in the valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to me, “Son of man, look toward the north.” So I looked, and there to the north, beside the entrance to the gate near the altar, stood the idol that had made the Lord so jealous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man,” he said, “do you see what they are doing? Do you see the detestable sins the people of Israel are committing to drive me from my Temple? But come, and you will see even more detestable sins than these!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought me to the door of the Temple courtyard, where I could see a hole in the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, “Now, son of man, dig into the wall.” So I dug into the wall and found a hidden doorway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go in,” he said, “and see the wicked and detestable sins they are committing in there!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I went in and saw the walls covered with engravings of all kinds of crawling animals and detestable creatures. I also saw the various idols worshiped by the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seventy leaders of Israel were standing there with Jaazaniah son of Shaphan in the center. Each of them held an incense burner, from which a cloud of incense rose above their heads.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to me, “Son of man, have you seen what the leaders of Israel are doing with their idols in dark rooms? They are saying, ‘The Lord doesn’t see us; he has deserted our land!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord added, “Come, and I will show you even more detestable sins than these!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought me to the north gate of the Lord’s Temple, and some women were sitting there, weeping for the god Tammuz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have you seen this?” he asked. “But I will show you even more detestable sins than these!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought me into the inner courtyard of the Lord’s Temple. At the entrance to the sanctuary, between the entry room and the bronze altar, there were about twenty-five men with their backs to the sanctuary of the Lord. They were facing east, bowing low to the ground, worshiping the sun!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have you seen this, son of man?” he asked. “Is it nothing to the people of Judah that they commit these detestable sins, leading the whole nation into violence, thumbing their noses at me, and provoking my anger?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, I will respond in fury. I will neither pity nor spare them. And though they cry for mercy, I will not listen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord thundered, “Bring on the men appointed to punish the city! Tell them to bring their weapons with them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six men soon appeared from the upper gate that faces north, each carrying a deadly weapon in his hand. With them was a man dressed in linen, who carried a writer’s case at his side. They all went into the Temple courtyard and stood beside the bronze altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the glory of the God of Israel rose up from between the cherubim, where it had rested, and moved to the entrance of the Temple. And the Lord called to the man dressed in linen who was carrying the writer’s case.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to him, “Walk through the streets of Jerusalem and put a mark on the foreheads of all who weep and sigh because of the detestable sins being committed in their city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I heard the Lord say to the other men, “Follow him through the city and kill everyone whose forehead is not marked. Show no mercy; have no pity!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kill them all—old and young, girls and women and little children. But do not touch anyone with the mark. Begin right here at the Temple.” So they began by killing the seventy leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Defile the Temple!” the Lord commanded. “Fill its courtyards with corpses. Go!” So they went and began killing throughout the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were out killing, I was all alone. I fell face down on the ground and cried out, “O Sovereign Lord! Will your fury against Jerusalem wipe out everyone left in Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, “The sins of the people of Israel and Judah are very, very great. The entire land is full of murder; the city is filled with injustice. They are saying, ‘The Lord doesn’t see it! The Lord has abandoned the land!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I will not spare them or have any pity on them. I will fully repay them for all they have done.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man in linen clothing, who carried the writer’s case, reported back and said, “I have done as you commanded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In my vision I saw what appeared to be a throne of blue lapis lazuli above the crystal surface over the heads of the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke to the man in linen clothing and said, “Go between the whirling wheels beneath the cherubim, and take a handful of burning coals and scatter them over the city.” He did this as I watched.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cherubim were standing at the south end of the Temple when the man went in, and the cloud of glory filled the inner courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the glory of the Lord rose up from above the cherubim and went over to the entrance of the Temple. The Temple was filled with this cloud of glory, and the courtyard glowed brightly with the glory of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The moving wings of the cherubim sounded like the voice of God Almighty and could be heard even in the outer courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to the man in linen clothing, “Go between the cherubim and take some burning coals from between the wheels.” So the man went in and stood beside one of the wheels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then one of the cherubim reached out his hand and took some live coals from the fire burning among them. He put the coals into the hands of the man in linen clothing, and the man took them and went out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (All the cherubim had what looked like human hands under their wings.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I looked, and each of the four cherubim had a wheel beside him, and the wheels sparkled like beryl.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All four wheels looked alike and were made the same; each wheel had a second wheel turning crosswise within it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cherubim could move in any of the four directions they faced, without turning as they moved. They went straight in the direction they faced, never turning aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both the cherubim and the wheels were covered with eyes. The cherubim had eyes all over their bodies, including their hands, their backs, and their wings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I heard someone refer to the wheels as “the whirling wheels.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of the four cherubim had four faces: the first was the face of an ox, the second was a human face, the third was the face of a lion, and the fourth was the face of an eagle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the cherubim rose upward. These were the same living beings I had seen beside the Kebar River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the cherubim moved, the wheels moved with them. When they lifted their wings to fly, the wheels stayed beside them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the cherubim stopped, the wheels stopped. When they flew upward, the wheels rose up, for the spirit of the living beings was in the wheels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the glory of the Lord moved out from the entrance of the Temple and hovered above the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And as I watched, the cherubim flew with their wheels to the east gate of the Lord’s Temple. And the glory of the God of Israel hovered above them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the same living beings I had seen beneath the God of Israel when I was by the Kebar River. I knew they were cherubim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for each had four faces and four wings and what looked like human hands under their wings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And their faces were just like the faces of the beings I had seen at the Kebar, and they traveled straight ahead, just as the others had.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit lifted me and brought me to the east gateway of the Lord’s Temple, where I saw twenty-five prominent men of the city. Among them were Jaazaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah, who were leaders among the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Spirit said to me, “Son of man, these are the men who are planning evil and giving wicked counsel in this city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They say to the people, ‘Is it not a good time to build houses? This city is like an iron pot. We are safe inside it like meat in a pot.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, son of man, prophesy against them loudly and clearly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came upon me, and he told me to say, “This is what the Lord says to the people of Israel: I know what you are saying, for I know every thought that comes into your minds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have murdered many in this city and filled its streets with the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: This city is an iron pot all right, but the pieces of meat are the victims of your injustice. As for you, I will soon drag you from this pot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring on you the sword of war you so greatly fear, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will drive you out of Jerusalem and hand you over to foreigners, who will carry out my judgments against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be slaughtered all the way to the borders of Israel. I will execute judgment on you, and you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, this city will not be an iron pot for you, and you will not be like meat safe inside it. I will judge you even to the borders of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you will know that I am the Lord. For you have refused to obey my decrees and regulations; instead, you have copied the standards of the nations around you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While I was still prophesying, Pelatiah son of Benaiah suddenly died. Then I fell face down on the ground and cried out, “O Sovereign Lord, are you going to kill everyone in Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, the people still left in Jerusalem are talking about you and your relatives and all the people of Israel who are in exile. They are saying, ‘Those people are far away from the Lord, so now he has given their land to us!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, tell the exiles, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Although I have scattered you in the countries of the world, I will be a sanctuary to you during your time in exile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Sovereign Lord, will gather you back from the nations where you have been scattered, and I will give you the land of Israel once again.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When the people return to their homeland, they will remove every trace of their vile images and detestable idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will give them singleness of heart and put a new spirit within them. I will take away their stony, stubborn heart and give them a tender, responsive heart,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so they will obey my decrees and regulations. Then they will truly be my people, and I will be their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for those who long for vile images and detestable idols, I will repay them fully for their sins. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the cherubim lifted their wings and rose into the air with their wheels beside them, and the glory of the God of Israel hovered above them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the glory of the Lord went up from the city and stopped above the mountain to the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward the Spirit of God carried me back again to Babylonia, to the people in exile there. And so ended the vision of my visit to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I told the exiles everything the Lord had shown me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again a message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, you live among rebels who have eyes but refuse to see. They have ears but refuse to hear. For they are a rebellious people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So now, son of man, pretend you are being sent into exile. Pack the few items an exile could carry, and leave your home to go somewhere else. Do this right in front of the people so they can see you. For perhaps they will pay attention to this, even though they are such rebels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring your baggage outside during the day so they can watch you. Then in the evening, as they are watching, leave your house as captives do when they begin a long march to distant lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dig a hole through the wall while they are watching and go out through it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they watch, lift your pack to your shoulders and walk away into the night. Cover your face so you cannot see the land you are leaving. For I have made you a sign for the people of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I did as I was told. In broad daylight I brought my pack outside, filled with the things I might carry into exile. Then in the evening while the people looked on, I dug through the wall with my hands and went out into the night with my pack on my shoulder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, these rebels, the people of Israel, have asked you what all this means.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: These actions contain a message for King Zedekiah in Jerusalem and for all the people of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Explain that your actions are a sign to show what will soon happen to them, for they will be driven into exile as captives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Even Zedekiah will leave Jerusalem at night through a hole in the wall, taking only what he can carry with him. He will cover his face, and his eyes will not see the land he is leaving.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will throw my net over him and capture him in my snare. I will bring him to Babylon, the land of the Babylonians, though he will never see it, and he will die there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will scatter his servants and warriors to the four winds and send the sword after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when I scatter them among the nations, they will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will spare a few of them from death by war, famine, or disease, so they can confess all their detestable sins to their captors. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, tremble as you eat your food. Shake with fear as you drink your water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the people, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says concerning those living in Israel and Jerusalem: They will eat their food with trembling and sip their water in despair, for their land will be stripped bare because of their violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cities will be destroyed and the farmland made desolate. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again a message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, you’ve heard that proverb they quote in Israel: ‘Time passes, and prophecies come to nothing.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the people, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will put an end to this proverb, and you will soon stop quoting it.’ Now give them this new proverb to replace the old one: ‘The time has come for every prophecy to be fulfilled!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “There will be no more false visions and flattering predictions in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I am the Lord! If I say it, it will happen. There will be no more delays, you rebels of Israel. I will fulfill my threat of destruction in your own lifetime. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, the people of Israel are saying, ‘He’s talking about the distant future. His visions won’t come true for a long, long time.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, tell them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: No more delay! I will now do everything I have threatened. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, prophesy against the false prophets of Israel who are inventing their own prophecies. Say to them, ‘Listen to the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: What sorrow awaits the false prophets who are following their own imaginations and have seen nothing at all!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “O people of Israel, these prophets of yours are like jackals digging in the ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have done nothing to repair the breaks in the walls around the nation. They have not helped it to stand firm in battle on the day of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, they have told lies and made false predictions. They say, ‘This message is from the Lord,’ even though the Lord never sent them. And yet they expect him to fulfill their prophecies!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Can your visions be anything but false if you claim, ‘This message is from the Lord,’ when I have not even spoken to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because what you say is false and your visions are a lie, I will stand against you, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will raise my fist against all the prophets who see false visions and make lying predictions, and they will be banished from the community of Israel. I will blot their names from Israel’s record books, and they will never again set foot in their own land. Then you will know that I am the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This will happen because these evil prophets deceive my people by saying, ‘All is peaceful’ when there is no peace at all! It’s as if the people have built a flimsy wall, and these prophets are trying to reinforce it by covering it with whitewash!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell these whitewashers that their wall will soon fall down. A heavy rainstorm will undermine it; great hailstones and mighty winds will knock it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the wall falls, the people will cry out, ‘What happened to your whitewash?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will sweep away your whitewashed wall with a storm of indignation, with a great flood of anger, and with hailstones of fury.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will break down your wall right to its foundation, and when it falls, it will crush you. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At last my anger against the wall and those who covered it with whitewash will be satisfied. Then I will say to you: ‘The wall and those who whitewashed it are both gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were lying prophets who claimed peace would come to Jerusalem when there was no peace. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, son of man, speak out against the women who prophesy from their own imaginations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: What sorrow awaits you women who are ensnaring the souls of my people, young and old alike. You tie magic charms on their wrists and furnish them with magic veils. Do you think you can trap others without bringing destruction on yourselves?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You bring shame on me among my people for a few handfuls of barley or a piece of bread. By lying to my people who love to listen to lies, you kill those who should not die, and you promise life to those who should not live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I am against all your magic charms, which you use to ensnare my people like birds. I will tear them from your arms, setting my people free like birds set free from a cage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will tear off the magic veils and save my people from your grasp. They will no longer be your victims. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have discouraged the righteous with your lies, but I didn’t want them to be sad. And you have encouraged the wicked by promising them life, even though they continue in their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of all this, you will no longer talk of seeing visions that you never saw, nor will you make predictions. For I will rescue my people from your grasp. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some of the leaders of Israel visited me, and while they were sitting with me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, these leaders have set up idols in their hearts. They have embraced things that will make them fall into sin. Why should I listen to their requests?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The people of Israel have set up idols in their hearts and fallen into sin, and then they go to a prophet asking for a message. So I, the Lord, will give them the kind of answer their great idolatry deserves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will do this to capture the minds and hearts of all my people who have turned from me to worship their detestable idols.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, tell the people of Israel, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Repent and turn away from your idols, and stop all your detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Lord, will answer all those, both Israelites and foreigners, who reject me and set up idols in their hearts and so fall into sin, and who then come to a prophet asking for my advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will turn against such people and make a terrible example of them, eliminating them from among my people. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘And if a prophet is deceived into giving a message, it is because I, the Lord, have deceived that prophet. I will lift my fist against such prophets and cut them off from the community of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: False prophets and those who seek their guidance will all be punished for their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, the people of Israel will learn not to stray from me, polluting themselves with sin. They will be my people, and I will be their God. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, suppose the people of a country were to sin against me, and I lifted my fist to crush them, cutting off their food supply and sending a famine to destroy both people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were there, their righteousness would save no one but themselves, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Or suppose I were to send wild animals to invade the country, kill the people, and make the land too desolate and dangerous to pass through.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, even if those three men were there, they wouldn’t be able to save their own sons or daughters. They alone would be saved, but the land would be made desolate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Or suppose I were to bring war against the land, and I sent enemy armies to destroy both people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, even if those three men were there, they wouldn’t be able to save their own sons or daughters. They alone would be saved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Or suppose I were to pour out my fury by sending an epidemic into the land, and the disease killed people and animals alike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were there, they wouldn’t be able to save their own sons or daughters. They alone would be saved by their righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now this is what the Sovereign Lord says: How terrible it will be when all four of these dreadful punishments fall upon Jerusalem—war, famine, wild animals, and disease—destroying all her people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet there will be survivors, and they will come here to join you as exiles in Babylon. You will see with your own eyes how wicked they are, and then you will feel better about what I have done to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you meet them and see their behavior, you will understand that these things are not being done to Israel without cause. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, how does a grapevine compare to a tree? Is a vine’s wood as useful as the wood of a tree?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Can its wood be used for making things, like pegs to hang up pots and pans?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, it can only be used for fuel, and even as fuel, it burns too quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Vines are useless both before and after being put into the fire!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And this is what the Sovereign Lord says: The people of Jerusalem are like grapevines growing among the trees of the forest. Since they are useless, I have thrown them on the fire to be burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will see to it that if they escape from one fire, they will fall into another. When I turn against them, you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will make the land desolate because my people have been unfaithful to me. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then another message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, confront Jerusalem with her detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give her this message from the Sovereign Lord: You are nothing but a Canaanite! Your father was an Amorite and your mother a Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day you were born, no one cared about you. Your umbilical cord was not cut, and you were never washed, rubbed with salt, and wrapped in cloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one had the slightest interest in you; no one pitied you or cared for you. On the day you were born, you were unwanted, dumped in a field and left to die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But I came by and saw you there, helplessly kicking about in your own blood. As you lay there, I said, ‘Live!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I helped you to thrive like a plant in the field. You grew up and became a beautiful jewel. Your breasts became full, and your body hair grew, but you were still naked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when I passed by again, I saw that you were old enough for love. So I wrapped my cloak around you to cover your nakedness and declared my marriage vows. I made a covenant with you, says the Sovereign Lord, and you became mine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then I bathed you and washed off your blood, and I rubbed fragrant oils into your skin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave you expensive clothing of fine linen and silk, beautifully embroidered, and sandals made of fine goatskin leather.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave you lovely jewelry, bracelets, beautiful necklaces,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a ring for your nose, earrings for your ears, and a lovely crown for your head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so you were adorned with gold and silver. Your clothes were made of fine linen and costly fabric and were beautifully embroidered. You ate the finest foods—choice flour, honey, and olive oil—and became more beautiful than ever. You looked like a queen, and so you were!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your fame soon spread throughout the world because of your beauty. I dressed you in my splendor and perfected your beauty, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But you thought your fame and beauty were your own. So you gave yourself as a prostitute to every man who came along. Your beauty was theirs for the asking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You used the lovely things I gave you to make shrines for idols, where you played the prostitute. Unbelievable! How could such a thing ever happen?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You took the very jewels and gold and silver ornaments I had given you and made statues of men and worshiped them. This is adultery against me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You used the beautifully embroidered clothes I gave you to dress your idols. Then you used my special oil and my incense to worship them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Imagine it! You set before them as a sacrifice the choice flour, olive oil, and honey I had given you, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then you took your sons and daughters—the children you had borne to me—and sacrificed them to your gods. Was your prostitution not enough?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Must you also slaughter my children by sacrificing them to idols?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all your years of adultery and detestable sin, you have not once remembered the days long ago when you lay naked in a field, kicking about in your own blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What sorrow awaits you, says the Sovereign Lord. In addition to all your other wickedness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you built a pagan shrine and put altars to idols in every town square.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On every street corner you defiled your beauty, offering your body to every passerby in an endless stream of prostitution.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you added lustful Egypt to your lovers, provoking my anger with your increasing promiscuity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why I struck you with my fist and reduced your boundaries. I handed you over to your enemies, the Philistines, and even they were shocked by your lewd conduct.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have prostituted yourself with the Assyrians, too. It seems you can never find enough new lovers! And after your prostitution there, you still were not satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You added to your lovers by embracing Babylonia, the land of merchants, but you still weren’t satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What a sick heart you have, says the Sovereign Lord, to do such things as these, acting like a shameless prostitute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You build your pagan shrines on every street corner and your altars to idols in every square. In fact, you have been worse than a prostitute, so eager for sin that you have not even demanded payment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, you are an adulterous wife who takes in strangers instead of her own husband.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Prostitutes charge for their services—but not you! You give gifts to your lovers, bribing them to come and have sex with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you are the opposite of other prostitutes. You pay your lovers instead of their paying you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, you prostitute, listen to this message from the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because you have poured out your lust and exposed yourself in prostitution to all your lovers, and because you have worshiped detestable idols, and because you have slaughtered your children as sacrifices to your gods,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: this is what I am going to do. I will gather together all your allies—the lovers with whom you have sinned, both those you loved and those you hated—and I will strip you naked in front of them so they can stare at you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish you for your murder and adultery. I will cover you with blood in my jealous fury.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will give you to these many nations who are your lovers, and they will destroy you. They will knock down your pagan shrines and the altars to your idols. They will strip you and take your beautiful jewels, leaving you stark naked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will band together in a mob to stone you and cut you up with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will burn your homes and punish you in front of many women. I will stop your prostitution and end your payments to your many lovers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then at last my fury against you will be spent, and my jealous anger will subside. I will be calm and will not be angry with you anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But first, because you have not remembered your youth but have angered me by doing all these evil things, I will fully repay you for all of your sins, says the Sovereign Lord. For you have added lewd acts to all your detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone who makes up proverbs will say of you, ‘Like mother, like daughter.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your mother loathed her husband and her children, and so do you. And you are exactly like your sisters, for they despised their husbands and their children. Truly your mother was a Hittite and your father an Amorite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your older sister was Samaria, who lived with her daughters in the north. Your younger sister was Sodom, who lived with her daughters in the south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you have not merely sinned as they did. You quickly surpassed them in corruption.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, Sodom and her daughters were never as wicked as you and your daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sodom’s sins were pride, gluttony, and laziness, while the poor and needy suffered outside her door.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She was proud and committed detestable sins, so I wiped her out, as you have seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Even Samaria did not commit half your sins. You have done far more detestable things than your sisters ever did. They seem righteous compared to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shame on you! Your sins are so terrible that you make your sisters seem righteous, even virtuous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But someday I will restore the fortunes of Sodom and Samaria, and I will restore you, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will be truly ashamed of everything you have done, for your sins make them feel good in comparison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, your sisters, Sodom and Samaria, and all their people will be restored, and at that time you also will be restored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In your proud days you held Sodom in contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now your greater wickedness has been exposed to all the world, and you are the one who is scorned—by Edom and all her neighbors and by Philistia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is your punishment for all your lewdness and detestable sins, says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will give you what you deserve, for you have taken your solemn vows lightly by breaking your covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet I will remember the covenant I made with you when you were young, and I will establish an everlasting covenant with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will remember with shame all the evil you have done. I will make your sisters, Samaria and Sodom, to be your daughters, even though they are not part of our covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will reaffirm my covenant with you, and you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will remember your sins and cover your mouth in silent shame when I forgive you of all that you have done. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, give this riddle, and tell this story to the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give them this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“A great eagle with broad wings and long feathers,
    covered with many-colored plumage,
    came to Lebanon.
He seized the top of a cedar tree
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and plucked off its highest branch.
He carried it away to a city filled with merchants.
    He planted it in a city of traders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He also took a seedling from the land
    and planted it in fertile soil.
He placed it beside a broad river,
    where it could grow like a willow tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It took root there and
    grew into a low, spreading vine.
Its branches turned up toward the eagle,
    and its roots grew down into the ground.
It produced strong branches
    and put out shoots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But then another great eagle came
    with broad wings and full plumage.
So the vine now sent its roots and branches
    toward him for water,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
even though it was already planted in good soil
    and had plenty of water
so it could grow into a splendid vine
    and produce rich leaves and luscious fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“So now the Sovereign Lord asks:
Will this vine grow and prosper?
    No! I will pull it up, roots and all!
I will cut off its fruit
    and let its leaves wither and die.
I will pull it up easily
    without a strong arm or a large army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But when the vine is transplanted,
    will it thrive?
No, it will wither away
    when the east wind blows against it.
It will die in the same good soil
    where it had grown so well.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say to these rebels of Israel: Don’t you understand the meaning of this riddle of the eagles? The king of Babylon came to Jerusalem, took away her king and princes, and brought them to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made a treaty with a member of the royal family and forced him to take an oath of loyalty. He also exiled Israel’s most influential leaders,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so Israel would not become strong again and revolt. Only by keeping her treaty with Babylon could Israel survive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Nevertheless, this man of Israel’s royal family rebelled against Babylon, sending ambassadors to Egypt to request a great army and many horses. Can Israel break her sworn treaties like that and get away with it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No! For as surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, the king of Israel will die in Babylon, the land of the king who put him in power and whose treaty he disregarded and broke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh and all his mighty army will fail to help Israel when the king of Babylon lays siege to Jerusalem again and destroys many lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the king of Israel disregarded his treaty and broke it after swearing to obey; therefore, he will not escape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So this is what the Sovereign Lord says: As surely as I live, I will punish him for breaking my covenant and disregarding the solemn oath he made in my name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will throw my net over him and capture him in my snare. I will bring him to Babylon and put him on trial for this treason against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all his best warriors will be killed in battle, and those who survive will be scattered to the four winds. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will take a branch from the top of a tall cedar, and I will plant it on the top of Israel’s highest mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will become a majestic cedar, sending forth its branches and producing seed. Birds of every sort will nest in it, finding shelter in the shade of its branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all the trees will know that it is I, the Lord, who cuts the tall tree down and makes the short tree grow tall. It is I who makes the green tree wither and gives the dead tree new life. I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do what I said!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then another message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why do you quote this proverb concerning the land of Israel: ‘The parents have eaten sour grapes, but their children’s mouths pucker at the taste’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, you will not quote this proverb anymore in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all people are mine to judge—both parents and children alike. And this is my rule: The person who sins is the one who will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Suppose a certain man is righteous and does what is just and right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He does not feast in the mountains before Israel’s idols or worship them. He does not commit adultery or have intercourse with a woman during her menstrual period.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is a merciful creditor, not keeping the items given as security by poor debtors. He does not rob the poor but instead gives food to the hungry and provides clothes for the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He grants loans without interest, stays away from injustice, is honest and fair when judging others,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and faithfully obeys my decrees and regulations. Anyone who does these things is just and will surely live, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But suppose that man has a son who grows up to be a robber or murderer and refuses to do what is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And that son does all the evil things his father would never do—he worships idols on the mountains, commits adultery,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: oppresses the poor and helpless, steals from debtors by refusing to let them redeem their security, worships idols, commits detestable sins,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and lends money at excessive interest. Should such a sinful person live? No! He must die and must take full blame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But suppose that sinful son, in turn, has a son who sees his father’s wickedness and decides against that kind of life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This son refuses to worship idols on the mountains and does not commit adultery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He does not exploit the poor, but instead is fair to debtors and does not rob them. He gives food to the hungry and provides clothes for the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He helps the poor, does not lend money at interest, and obeys all my regulations and decrees. Such a person will not die because of his father’s sins; he will surely live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the father will die for his many sins—for being cruel, robbing people, and doing what was clearly wrong among his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘What?’ you ask. ‘Doesn’t the child pay for the parent’s sins?’ No! For if the child does what is just and right and keeps my decrees, that child will surely live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The person who sins is the one who will die. The child will not be punished for the parent’s sins, and the parent will not be punished for the child’s sins. Righteous people will be rewarded for their own righteous behavior, and wicked people will be punished for their own wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if wicked people turn away from all their sins and begin to obey my decrees and do what is just and right, they will surely live and not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All their past sins will be forgotten, and they will live because of the righteous things they have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do you think that I like to see wicked people die? says the Sovereign Lord. Of course not! I want them to turn from their wicked ways and live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, if righteous people turn from their righteous behavior and start doing sinful things and act like other sinners, should they be allowed to live? No, of course not! All their righteous acts will be forgotten, and they will die for their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yet you say, ‘The Lord isn’t doing what’s right!’ Listen to me, O people of Israel. Am I the one not doing what’s right, or is it you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When righteous people turn from their righteous behavior and start doing sinful things, they will die for it. Yes, they will die because of their sinful deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if wicked people turn from their wickedness, obey the law, and do what is just and right, they will save their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will live because they thought it over and decided to turn from their sins. Such people will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And yet the people of Israel keep saying, ‘The Lord isn’t doing what’s right!’ O people of Israel, it is you who are not doing what’s right, not I.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, I will judge each of you, O people of Israel, according to your actions, says the Sovereign Lord. Repent, and turn from your sins. Don’t let them destroy you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put all your rebellion behind you, and find yourselves a new heart and a new spirit. For why should you die, O people of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I don’t want you to die, says the Sovereign Lord. Turn back and live!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Sing this funeral song for the princes of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What is your mother?
    A lioness among lions!
She lay down among the young lions
    and reared her cubs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She raised one of her cubs
    to become a strong young lion.
He learned to hunt and devour prey,
    and he became a man-eater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the nations heard about him,
    and he was trapped in their pit.
They led him away with hooks
    to the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When the lioness saw
    that her hopes for him were gone,
she took another of her cubs
    and taught him to be a strong young lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He prowled among the other lions
    and stood out among them in his strength.
He learned to hunt and devour prey,
    and he, too, became a man-eater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He demolished fortresses
    and destroyed their towns and cities.
Their farms were desolated,
    and their crops were destroyed.
The land and its people trembled in fear
    when they heard him roar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the armies of the nations attacked him,
    surrounding him from every direction.
They threw a net over him
    and captured him in their pit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With hooks, they dragged him into a cage
    and brought him before the king of Babylon.
They held him in captivity,
    so his voice could never again be heard
    on the mountains of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Your mother was like a vine
    planted by the water’s edge.
It had lush, green foliage
    because of the abundant water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its branches became strong—
    strong enough to be a ruler’s scepter.
It grew very tall,
    towering above all others.
It stood out because of its height
    and its many lush branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the vine was uprooted in fury
    and thrown down to the ground.
The desert wind dried up its fruit
    and tore off its strong branches,
so that it withered
    and was destroyed by fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now the vine is transplanted to the wilderness,
    where the ground is hard and dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A fire has burst out from its branches
    and devoured its fruit.
Its remaining limbs are not
    strong enough to be a ruler’s scepter.
“This is a funeral song, and it will be used in a funeral.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On August 14, during the seventh year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, some of the leaders of Israel came to request a message from the Lord. They sat down in front of me to wait for his reply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, tell the leaders of Israel, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: How dare you come to ask me for a message? As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, I will tell you nothing!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, bring charges against them and condemn them. Make them realize how detestable the sins of their ancestors really were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give them this message from the Sovereign Lord: When I chose Israel—when I revealed myself to the descendants of Jacob in Egypt—I took a solemn oath that I, the Lord, would be their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I took a solemn oath that day that I would bring them out of Egypt to a land I had discovered and explored for them—a good land, a land flowing with milk and honey, the best of all lands anywhere.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I said to them, ‘Each of you, get rid of the vile images you are so obsessed with. Do not defile yourselves with the idols of Egypt, for I am the Lord your God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But they rebelled against me and would not listen. They did not get rid of the vile images they were obsessed with, or forsake the idols of Egypt. Then I threatened to pour out my fury on them to satisfy my anger while they were still in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I didn’t do it, for I acted to protect the honor of my name. I would not allow shame to be brought on my name among the surrounding nations who saw me reveal myself by bringing the Israelites out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I brought them out of Egypt and led them into the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There I gave them my decrees and regulations so they could find life by keeping them.
verses.speaker: Narrator
