verses.text: And I gave them my Sabbath days of rest as a sign between them and me. It was to remind them that I am the Lord, who had set them apart to be holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But the people of Israel rebelled against me, and they refused to obey my decrees there in the wilderness. They wouldn’t obey my regulations even though obedience would have given them life. They also violated my Sabbath days. So I threatened to pour out my fury on them, and I made plans to utterly consume them in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But again I held back in order to protect the honor of my name before the nations who had seen my power in bringing Israel out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I took a solemn oath against them in the wilderness. I swore I would not bring them into the land I had given them, a land flowing with milk and honey, the most beautiful place on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For they had rejected my regulations, refused to follow my decrees, and violated my Sabbath days. Their hearts were given to their idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, I took pity on them and held back from destroying them in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then I warned their children not to follow in their parents’ footsteps, defiling themselves with their idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I am the Lord your God,’ I told them. ‘Follow my decrees, pay attention to my regulations,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and keep my Sabbath days holy, for they are a sign to remind you that I am the Lord your God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But their children, too, rebelled against me. They refused to keep my decrees and follow my regulations, even though obedience would have given them life. And they also violated my Sabbath days. So again I threatened to pour out my fury on them in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, I withdrew my judgment against them to protect the honor of my name before the nations that had seen my power in bringing them out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I took a solemn oath against them in the wilderness. I swore I would scatter them among all the nations
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they did not obey my regulations. They scorned my decrees by violating my Sabbath days and longing for the idols of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave them over to worthless decrees and regulations that would not lead to life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I let them pollute themselves with the very gifts I had given them, and I allowed them to give their firstborn children as offerings to their gods—so I might devastate them and remind them that I alone am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, son of man, give the people of Israel this message from the Sovereign Lord: Your ancestors continued to blaspheme and betray me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for when I brought them into the land I had promised them, they offered sacrifices on every high hill and under every green tree they saw! They roused my fury as they offered up sacrifices to their gods. They brought their perfumes and incense and poured out their liquid offerings to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to them, ‘What is this high place where you are going?’ (This kind of pagan shrine has been called Bamah—‘high place’—ever since.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, give the people of Israel this message from the Sovereign Lord: Do you plan to pollute yourselves just as your ancestors did? Do you intend to keep prostituting yourselves by worshiping vile images?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For when you offer gifts to them and give your little children to be burned as sacrifices, you continue to pollute yourselves with idols to this day. Should I allow you to ask for a message from me, O people of Israel? As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, I will tell you nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You say, ‘We want to be like the nations all around us, who serve idols of wood and stone.’ But what you have in mind will never happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, I will rule over you with an iron fist in great anger and with awesome power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And in anger I will reach out with my strong hand and powerful arm, and I will bring you back from the lands where you are scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring you into the wilderness of the nations, and there I will judge you face to face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will judge you there just as I did your ancestors in the wilderness after bringing them out of Egypt, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will examine you carefully and hold you to the terms of the covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will purge you of all those who rebel and revolt against me. I will bring them out of the countries where they are in exile, but they will never enter the land of Israel. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for you, O people of Israel, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Go right ahead and worship your idols, but sooner or later you will obey me and will stop bringing shame on my holy name by worshiping idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For on my holy mountain, the great mountain of Israel, says the Sovereign Lord, the people of Israel will someday worship me, and I will accept them. There I will require that you bring me all your offerings and choice gifts and sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I bring you home from exile, you will be like a pleasing sacrifice to me. And I will display my holiness through you as all the nations watch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then when I have brought you home to the land I promised with a solemn oath to give to your ancestors, you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will look back on all the ways you defiled yourselves and will hate yourselves because of the evil you have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will know that I am the Lord, O people of Israel, when I have honored my name by treating you mercifully in spite of your wickedness. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face the south and speak out against it; prophesy against the brushlands of the Negev.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the southern wilderness, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Hear the word of the Lord! I will set you on fire, and every tree, both green and dry, will be burned. The terrible flames will not be quenched and will scorch everything from south to north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And everyone in the world will see that I, the Lord, have set this fire. It will not be put out.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I said, “O Sovereign Lord, they are saying of me, ‘He only talks in riddles!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face Jerusalem and prophesy against Israel and her sanctuaries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell her, ‘This is what the Lord says: I am your enemy, O Israel, and I am about to unsheath my sword to destroy your people—the righteous and the wicked alike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, I will cut off both the righteous and the wicked! I will draw my sword against everyone in the land from south to north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone in the world will know that I am the Lord. My sword is in my hand, and it will not return to its sheath until its work is finished.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, groan before the people! Groan before them with bitter anguish and a broken heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they ask why you are groaning, tell them, ‘I groan because of the terrifying news I have heard. When it comes true, the boldest heart will melt with fear; all strength will disappear. Every spirit will faint; strong knees will become as weak as water. And the Sovereign Lord says: It is coming! It’s on its way!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, give the people this message from the Lord:
“A sword, a sword
    is being sharpened and polished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is sharpened for terrible slaughter
    and polished to flash like lightning!
Now will you laugh?
    Those far stronger than you have fallen beneath its power!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, the sword is now being sharpened and polished;
    it is being prepared for the executioner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, cry out and wail;
    pound your thighs in anguish,
for that sword will slaughter my people and their leaders—
    everyone will die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It will put them all to the test.
    What chance do they have?
    says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, prophesy to them
    and clap your hands.
Then take the sword and brandish it twice,
    even three times,
to symbolize the great massacre,
    the great massacre facing them on every side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let their hearts melt with terror,
    for the sword glitters at every gate.
It flashes like lightning
    and is polished for slaughter!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O sword, slash to the right,
    then slash to the left,
wherever you will,
    wherever you want.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I, too, will clap my hands,
    and I will satisfy my fury.
    I, the Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, make a map and trace two routes on it for the sword of Babylon’s king to follow. Put a signpost on the road that comes out of Babylon where the road forks into two—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: one road going to Ammon and its capital, Rabbah, and the other to Judah and fortified Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon now stands at the fork, uncertain whether to attack Jerusalem or Rabbah. He calls his magicians to look for omens. They cast lots by shaking arrows from the quiver. They inspect the livers of animal sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The omen in his right hand says, ‘Jerusalem!’ With battering rams his soldiers will go against the gates, shouting for the kill. They will put up siege towers and build ramps against the walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Jerusalem will think it is a false omen, because of their treaty with the Babylonians. But the king of Babylon will remind the people of their rebellion. Then he will attack and capture them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Again and again you remind me of your sin and your guilt. You don’t even try to hide it! In everything you do, your sins are obvious for all to see. So now the time of your punishment has come!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “O you corrupt and wicked prince of Israel, your final day of reckoning is here!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Sovereign Lord says:
“Take off your jeweled crown,
    for the old order changes.
Now the lowly will be exalted,
    and the mighty will be brought down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Destruction! Destruction!
    I will surely destroy the kingdom.
And it will not be restored until the one appears
    who has the right to judge it.
Then I will hand it over to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“And now, son of man, prophesy concerning the Ammonites and their mockery. Give them this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“A sword, a sword
    is drawn for your slaughter.
It is polished to destroy,
    flashing like lightning!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your prophets have given false visions,
    and your fortune-tellers have told lies.
The sword will fall on the necks of the wicked
    for whom the day of final reckoning has come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Now return the sword to its sheath,
    for in your own country,
the land of your birth,
    I will pass judgment upon you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will pour out my fury on you
    and blow on you with the fire of my anger.
I will hand you over to cruel men
    who are skilled in destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be fuel for the fire,
    and your blood will be spilled in your own land.
You will be utterly wiped out,
    your memory lost to history,
    for I, the Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, are you ready to judge Jerusalem? Are you ready to judge this city of murderers? Publicly denounce her detestable sins,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and give her this message from the Sovereign Lord: O city of murderers, doomed and damned—city of idols, filthy and foul—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you are guilty because of the blood you have shed. You are defiled because of the idols you have made. Your day of destruction has come! You have reached the end of your years. I will make you an object of mockery throughout the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O infamous city, filled with confusion, you will be mocked by people far and near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Every leader in Israel who lives within your walls is bent on murder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fathers and mothers are treated with contempt. Foreigners are forced to pay for protection. Orphans and widows are wronged and oppressed among you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You despise my holy things and violate my Sabbath days of rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People accuse others falsely and send them to their death. You are filled with idol worshipers and people who do obscene things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Men sleep with their fathers’ wives and force themselves on women who are menstruating.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Within your walls live men who commit adultery with their neighbors’ wives, who defile their daughters-in-law, or who rape their own sisters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are hired murderers, loan racketeers, and extortioners everywhere. They never even think of me and my commands, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But now I clap my hands in indignation over your dishonest gain and bloodshed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How strong and courageous will you be in my day of reckoning? I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do what I said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will scatter you among the nations and purge you of your wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when I have been dishonored among the nations because of you, you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, the people of Israel are the worthless slag that remains after silver is smelted. They are the dross that is left over—a useless mixture of copper, tin, iron, and lead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So tell them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because you are all worthless slag, I will bring you to my crucible in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as silver, copper, iron, lead, and tin are melted down in a furnace, I will melt you down in the heat of my fury.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will gather you together and blow the fire of my anger upon you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you will melt like silver in fierce heat. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have poured out my fury on you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again a message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, give the people of Israel this message: In the day of my indignation, you will be like a polluted land, a land without rain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your princes plot conspiracies just as lions stalk their prey. They devour innocent people, seizing treasures and extorting wealth. They make many widows in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your priests have violated my instructions and defiled my holy things. They make no distinction between what is holy and what is not. And they do not teach my people the difference between what is ceremonially clean and unclean. They disregard my Sabbath days so that I am dishonored among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your leaders are like wolves who tear apart their victims. They actually destroy people’s lives for money!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And your prophets cover up for them by announcing false visions and making lying predictions. They say, ‘My message is from the Sovereign Lord,’ when the Lord hasn’t spoken a single word to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even common people oppress the poor, rob the needy, and deprive foreigners of justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I looked for someone who might rebuild the wall of righteousness that guards the land. I searched for someone to stand in the gap in the wall so I wouldn’t have to destroy the land, but I found no one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now I will pour out my fury on them, consuming them with the fire of my anger. I will heap on their heads the full penalty for all their sins. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, once there were two sisters who were daughters of the same mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They became prostitutes in Egypt. Even as young girls, they allowed men to fondle their breasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The older girl was named Oholah, and her sister was Oholibah. I married them, and they bore me sons and daughters. I am speaking of Samaria and Jerusalem, for Oholah is Samaria and Oholibah is Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then Oholah lusted after other lovers instead of me, and she gave her love to the Assyrian officers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were all attractive young men, captains and commanders dressed in handsome blue, charioteers driving their horses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so she prostituted herself with the most desirable men of Assyria, worshiping their idols and defiling herself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For when she left Egypt, she did not leave her spirit of prostitution behind. She was still as lewd as in her youth, when the Egyptians slept with her, fondled her breasts, and used her as a prostitute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And so I handed her over to her Assyrian lovers, whom she desired so much.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They stripped her, took away her children as their slaves, and then killed her. After she received her punishment, her reputation was known to every woman in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Yet even though Oholibah saw what had happened to Oholah, her sister, she followed right in her footsteps. And she was even more depraved, abandoning herself to her lust and prostitution.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She fawned over all the Assyrian officers—those captains and commanders in handsome uniforms, those charioteers driving their horses—all of them attractive young men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I saw the way she was going, defiling herself just like her older sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then she carried her prostitution even further. She fell in love with pictures that were painted on a wall—pictures of Babylonian military officers, outfitted in striking red uniforms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Handsome belts encircled their waists, and flowing turbans crowned their heads. They were dressed like chariot officers from the land of Babylonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she saw these paintings, she longed to give herself to them, so she sent messengers to Babylonia to invite them to come to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they came and committed adultery with her, defiling her in the bed of love. After being defiled, however, she rejected them in disgust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In the same way, I became disgusted with Oholibah and rejected her, just as I had rejected her sister, because she flaunted herself before them and gave herself to satisfy their lusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet she turned to even greater prostitution, remembering her youth when she was a prostitute in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She lusted after lovers with genitals as large as a donkey’s and emissions like those of a horse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so, Oholibah, you relived your former days as a young girl in Egypt, when you first allowed your breasts to be fondled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, Oholibah, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will send your lovers against you from every direction—those very nations from which you turned away in disgust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Babylonians will come with all the Chaldeans from Pekod and Shoa and Koa. And all the Assyrians will come with them—handsome young captains, commanders, chariot officers, and other high-ranking officers, all riding their horses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will all come against you from the north with chariots, wagons, and a great army prepared for attack. They will take up positions on every side, surrounding you with men armed with shields and helmets. And I will hand you over to them for punishment so they can do with you as they please.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will turn my jealous anger against you, and they will deal harshly with you. They will cut off your nose and ears, and any survivors will then be slaughtered by the sword. Your children will be taken away as captives, and everything that is left will be burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will strip you of your beautiful clothes and jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, I will put a stop to the lewdness and prostitution you brought from Egypt. You will never again cast longing eyes on those things or fondly remember your time in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will surely hand you over to your enemies, to those you loathe, those you rejected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will treat you with hatred and rob you of all you own, leaving you stark naked. The shame of your prostitution will be exposed to all the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You brought all this on yourself by prostituting yourself to other nations, defiling yourself with all their idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you have followed in your sister’s footsteps, I will force you to drink the same cup of terror she drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Yes, this is what the Sovereign Lord says:
“You will drink from your sister’s cup of terror,
    a cup that is large and deep.
It is filled to the brim
    with scorn and derision.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You will drain that cup of terror
    to the very bottom.
Then you will smash it to pieces
    and beat your breast in anguish.
    I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And because you have forgotten me and turned your back on me, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: You must bear the consequences of all your lewdness and prostitution.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to me, “Son of man, you must accuse Oholah and Oholibah of all their detestable sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have committed both adultery and murder—adultery by worshiping idols and murder by burning as sacrifices the children they bore to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, they have defiled my Temple and violated my Sabbath day!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the very day that they sacrificed their children to their idols, they boldly came into my Temple to worship! They came in and defiled my house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You sisters sent messengers to distant lands to get men. Then when they arrived, you bathed yourselves, painted your eyelids, and put on your finest jewels for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You sat with them on a beautifully embroidered couch and put my incense and my special oil on a table that was spread before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From your room came the sound of many men carousing. They were lustful men and drunkards from the wilderness, who put bracelets on your wrists and beautiful crowns on your heads.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I said, ‘If they really want to have sex with old worn-out prostitutes like these, let them!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And that is what they did. They had sex with Oholah and Oholibah, these shameless prostitutes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But righteous people will judge these sister cities for what they really are—adulterers and murderers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Bring an army against them and hand them over to be terrorized and plundered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For their enemies will stone them and kill them with swords. They will butcher their sons and daughters and burn their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, I will put an end to lewdness and idolatry in the land, and my judgment will be a warning to all women not to follow your wicked example.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be fully repaid for all your prostitution—your worship of idols. Yes, you will suffer the full penalty. Then you will know that I am the Sovereign Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On January 15, during the ninth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, write down today’s date, because on this very day the king of Babylon is beginning his attack against Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then give these rebels an illustration with this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“Put a pot on the fire,
    and pour in some water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fill it with choice pieces of meat—
    the rump and the shoulder
    and all the most tender cuts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Use only the best sheep from the flock,
    and heap fuel on the fire beneath the pot.
Bring the pot to a boil,
    and cook the bones along with the meat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Now this is what the Sovereign Lord says:
What sorrow awaits Jerusalem,
    the city of murderers!
She is a cooking pot
    whose corruption can’t be cleaned out.
Take the meat out in random order,
    for no piece is better than another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the blood of her murders
    is splashed on the rocks.
It isn’t even spilled on the ground,
    where the dust could cover it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I will splash her blood on a rock
    for all to see,
an expression of my anger
    and vengeance against her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“This is what the Sovereign Lord says:
What sorrow awaits Jerusalem,
    the city of murderers!
    I myself will pile up the fuel beneath her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, heap on the wood!
    Let the fire roar to make the pot boil.
Cook the meat with many spices,
    and afterward burn the bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now set the empty pot on the coals.
    Heat it red hot!
    Burn away the filth and corruption.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Your impurity is your lewdness
    and the corruption of your idolatry.
I tried to cleanse you,
    but you refused.
So now you will remain in your filth
    until my fury against you has been satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I, the Lord, have spoken! The time has come, and I won’t hold back. I will not change my mind, and I will have no pity on you. You will be judged on the basis of all your wicked actions, says the Sovereign Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, with one blow I will take away your dearest treasure. Yet you must not show any sorrow at her death. Do not weep; let there be no tears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Groan silently, but let there be no wailing at her grave. Do not uncover your head or take off your sandals. Do not perform the usual rituals of mourning or accept any food brought to you by consoling friends.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I proclaimed this to the people the next morning, and in the evening my wife died. The next morning I did everything I had been told to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people asked, “What does all this mean? What are you trying to tell us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I said to them, “A message came to me from the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I was told to give this message to the people of Israel. This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will defile my Temple, the source of your security and pride, the place your heart delights in. Your sons and daughters whom you left behind in Judah will be slaughtered by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will do as Ezekiel has done. You will not mourn in public or console yourselves by eating the food brought by friends.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your heads will remain covered, and your sandals will not be taken off. You will not mourn or weep, but you will waste away because of your sins. You will groan among yourselves for all the evil you have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ezekiel is an example for you; you will do just as he has done. And when that time comes, you will know that I am the Sovereign Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to me, “Son of man, on the day I take away their stronghold—their joy and glory, their heart’s desire, their dearest treasure—I will also take away their sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And on that day a survivor from Jerusalem will come to you in Babylon and tell you what has happened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when he arrives, your voice will suddenly return so you can talk to him, and you will be a symbol for these people. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face the land of Ammon and prophesy against its people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give the Ammonites this message from the Sovereign Lord: Hear the word of the Sovereign Lord! Because you cheered when my Temple was defiled, mocked Israel in her desolation, and laughed at Judah as she went away into exile,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will allow nomads from the eastern deserts to overrun your country. They will set up their camps among you and pitch their tents on your land. They will harvest all your fruit and drink the milk from your livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will turn the city of Rabbah into a pasture for camels, and all the land of the Ammonites into a resting place for sheep and goats. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because you clapped and danced and cheered with glee at the destruction of my people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will raise my fist of judgment against you. I will give you as plunder to many nations. I will cut you off from being a nation and destroy you completely. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because the people of Moab have said that Judah is just like all the other nations,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will open up their eastern flank and wipe out their glorious frontier towns—Beth-jeshimoth, Baal-meon, and Kiriathaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will hand Moab over to nomads from the eastern deserts, just as I handed over Ammon. Yes, the Ammonites will no longer be counted among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way, I will bring my judgment down on the Moabites. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The people of Edom have sinned greatly by avenging themselves against the people of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, says the Sovereign Lord, I will raise my fist of judgment against Edom. I will wipe out its people and animals with the sword. I will make a wasteland of everything from Teman to Dedan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will accomplish this by the hand of my people of Israel. They will carry out my vengeance with anger, and Edom will know that this vengeance is from me. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The people of Philistia have acted against Judah out of bitter revenge and long-standing contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will raise my fist of judgment against the land of the Philistines. I will wipe out the Kerethites and utterly destroy the people who live by the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will execute terrible vengeance against them to punish them for what they have done. And when I have inflicted my revenge, they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On February 3, during the twelfth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, Tyre has rejoiced over the fall of Jerusalem, saying, ‘Ha! She who was the gateway to the rich trade routes to the east has been broken, and I am the heir! Because she has been made desolate, I will become wealthy!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I am your enemy, O Tyre, and I will bring many nations against you, like the waves of the sea crashing against your shoreline.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will destroy the walls of Tyre and tear down its towers. I will scrape away its soil and make it a bare rock!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be just a rock in the sea, a place for fishermen to spread their nets, for I have spoken, says the Sovereign Lord. Tyre will become the prey of many nations,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and its mainland villages will be destroyed by the sword. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: From the north I will bring King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon against Tyre. He is king of kings and brings his horses, chariots, charioteers, and great army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: First he will destroy your mainland villages. Then he will attack you by building a siege wall, constructing a ramp, and raising a roof of shields against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will pound your walls with battering rams and demolish your towers with sledgehammers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The hooves of his horses will choke the city with dust, and the noise of the charioteers and chariot wheels will shake your walls as they storm through your broken gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His horsemen will trample through every street in the city. They will butcher your people, and your strong pillars will topple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They will plunder all your riches and merchandise and break down your walls. They will destroy your lovely homes and dump your stones and timbers and even your dust into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will stop the music of your songs. No more will the sound of harps be heard among your people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make your island a bare rock, a place for fishermen to spread their nets. You will never be rebuilt, for I, the Lord, have spoken. Yes, the Sovereign Lord has spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says to Tyre: The whole coastline will tremble at the sound of your fall, as the screams of the wounded echo in the continuing slaughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the seaport rulers will step down from their thrones and take off their royal robes and beautiful clothing. They will sit on the ground trembling with horror at your destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then they will wail for you, singing this funeral song: 
“O famous island city,
    once ruler of the sea,
    how you have been destroyed!
Your people, with their naval power,
    once spread fear around the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now the coastlands tremble at your fall.
    The islands are dismayed as you disappear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will make Tyre an uninhabited ruin, like many others. I will bury you beneath the terrible waves of enemy attack. Great seas will swallow you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send you to the pit to join those who descended there long ago. Your city will lie in ruins, buried beneath the earth, like those in the pit who have entered the world of the dead. You will have no place of respect here in the land of the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring you to a terrible end, and you will exist no more. You will be looked for, but you will never again be found. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, sing a funeral song for Tyre,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that mighty gateway to the sea, the trading center of the world. Give Tyre this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“You boasted, O Tyre,
    ‘My beauty is perfect!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You extended your boundaries into the sea.
    Your builders made your beauty perfect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You were like a great ship
    built of the finest cypress from Senir.
They took a cedar from Lebanon
    to make a mast for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They carved your oars
    from the oaks of Bashan.
Your deck of pine from the coasts of Cyprus
    was inlaid with ivory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your sails were made of Egypt’s finest linen,
    and they flew as a banner above you.
You stood beneath blue and purple awnings
    made bright with dyes from the coasts of Elishah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your oarsmen came from Sidon and Arvad;
    your helmsmen were skilled men from Tyre itself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wise old craftsmen from Gebal did the caulking.
    Ships from every land came with goods to barter for your trade.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Men from distant Persia, Lydia, and Libya served in your great army. They hung their shields and helmets on your walls, giving you great honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Men from Arvad and Helech stood on your walls. Your towers were manned by men from Gammad. Their shields hung on your walls, completing your beauty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tarshish sent merchants to buy your wares in exchange for silver, iron, tin, and lead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Merchants from Greece, Tubal, and Meshech brought slaves and articles of bronze to trade with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “From Beth-togarmah came riding horses, chariot horses, and mules, all in exchange for your goods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Merchants came to you from Dedan. Numerous coastlands were your captive markets; they brought payment in ivory tusks and ebony wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Syria sent merchants to buy your rich variety of goods. They traded turquoise, purple dyes, embroidery, fine linen, and jewelry of coral and rubies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah and Israel traded for your wares, offering wheat from Minnith, figs, honey, olive oil, and balm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Damascus sent merchants to buy your rich variety of goods, bringing wine from Helbon and white wool from Zahar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greeks from Uzal came to trade for your merchandise. Wrought iron, cassia, and fragrant calamus were bartered for your wares.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Dedan sent merchants to trade their expensive saddle blankets with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Arabians and the princes of Kedar sent merchants to trade lambs and rams and male goats in exchange for your goods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The merchants of Sheba and Raamah came with all kinds of spices, jewels, and gold in exchange for your wares.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Haran, Canneh, Eden, Sheba, Asshur, and Kilmad came with their merchandise, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought choice fabrics to trade—blue cloth, embroidery, and multicolored carpets rolled up and bound with cords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ships of Tarshish were your ocean caravans. Your island warehouse was filled to the brim!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But look! Your oarsmen
    have taken you into stormy seas!
A mighty eastern gale
    has wrecked you in the heart of the sea!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everything is lost—
    your riches and wares,
your sailors and pilots,
    your ship builders, merchants, and warriors.
On the day of your ruin,
    everyone on board sinks into the depths of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your cities by the sea tremble
    as your pilots cry out in terror.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the oarsmen abandon their ships;
    the sailors and pilots stand on the shore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They cry aloud over you
    and weep bitterly.
They throw dust on their heads
    and roll in ashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They shave their heads in grief for you
    and dress themselves in burlap.
They weep for you with bitter anguish
    and deep mourning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As they wail and mourn over you,
    they sing this sad funeral song:
‘Was there ever such a city as Tyre,
    now silent at the bottom of the sea?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The merchandise you traded
    satisfied the desires of many nations.
Kings at the ends of the earth
    were enriched by your trade.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now you are a wrecked ship,
    broken at the bottom of the sea.
All your merchandise and crew
    have gone down with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All who live along the coastlands
    are appalled at your terrible fate.
Their kings are filled with horror
    and look on with twisted faces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The merchants among the nations
    shake their heads at the sight of you,
for you have come to a horrible end
    and will exist no more.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, give the prince of Tyre this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“In your great pride you claim, ‘I am a god!
    I sit on a divine throne in the heart of the sea.’
But you are only a man and not a god,
    though you boast that you are a god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You regard yourself as wiser than Daniel
    and think no secret is hidden from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With your wisdom and understanding you have amassed great wealth—
    gold and silver for your treasuries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, your wisdom has made you very rich,
    and your riches have made you very proud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says:
Because you think you are as wise as a god,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will now bring against you a foreign army,
    the terror of the nations.
They will draw their swords against your marvelous wisdom
    and defile your splendor!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will bring you down to the pit,
    and you will die in the heart of the sea,
    pierced with many wounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you then boast, ‘I am a god!’
    to those who kill you?
To them you will be no god
    but merely a man!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will die like an outcast
    at the hands of foreigners.
    I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this further message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, sing this funeral song for the king of Tyre. Give him this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“You were the model of perfection,
    full of wisdom and exquisite in beauty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You were in Eden,
    the garden of God.
Your clothing was adorned with every precious stone—
    red carnelian, pale-green peridot, white moonstone,
    blue-green beryl, onyx, green jasper,
    blue lapis lazuli, turquoise, and emerald—
all beautifully crafted for you
    and set in the finest gold.
They were given to you
    on the day you were created.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I ordained and anointed you
    as the mighty angelic guardian.
You had access to the holy mountain of God
    and walked among the stones of fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You were blameless in all you did
    from the day you were created
    until the day evil was found in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your rich commerce led you to violence,
    and you sinned.
So I banished you in disgrace
    from the mountain of God.
I expelled you, O mighty guardian,
    from your place among the stones of fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your heart was filled with pride
    because of all your beauty.
Your wisdom was corrupted
    by your love of splendor.
So I threw you to the ground
    and exposed you to the curious gaze of kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You defiled your sanctuaries
    with your many sins and your dishonest trade.
So I brought fire out from within you,
    and it consumed you.
I reduced you to ashes on the ground
    in the sight of all who were watching.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All who knew you are appalled at your fate.
    You have come to a terrible end,
    and you will exist no more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then another message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face the city of Sidon and prophesy against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give the people of Sidon this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“I am your enemy, O Sidon,
    and I will reveal my glory by what I do to you.
When I bring judgment against you
    and reveal my holiness among you,
everyone watching will know
    that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will send a plague against you,
    and blood will be spilled in your streets.
The attack will come from every direction,
    and your people will lie slaughtered within your walls.
Then everyone will know
    that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No longer will Israel’s scornful neighbors
    prick and tear at her like briers and thorns.
For then they will know
    that I am the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The people of Israel will again live in their own land, the land I gave my servant Jacob. For I will gather them from the distant lands where I have scattered them. I will reveal to the nations of the world my holiness among my people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will live safely in Israel and build homes and plant vineyards. And when I punish the neighboring nations that treated them with contempt, they will know that I am the Lord their God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On January 7, during the tenth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face Egypt and prophesy against Pharaoh the king and all the people of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give them this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“I am your enemy, O Pharaoh, king of Egypt—
    you great monster, lurking in the streams of the Nile.
For you have said, ‘The Nile River is mine;
    I made it for myself.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will put hooks in your jaws
    and drag you out on the land
    with fish sticking to your scales.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will leave you and all your fish
    stranded in the wilderness to die.
You will lie unburied on the open ground,
    for I have given you as food to the wild animals and birds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the people of Egypt will know that I am the Lord,
    for to Israel you were just a staff made of reeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Israel leaned on you,
    you splintered and broke
    and stabbed her in the armpit.
When she put her weight on you,
    you collapsed, and her legs gave way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will bring an army against you, O Egypt, and destroy both people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The land of Egypt will become a desolate wasteland, and the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.
“Because you said, ‘The Nile River is mine; I made it,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am now the enemy of both you and your river. I will make the land of Egypt a totally desolate wasteland, from Migdol to Aswan, as far south as the border of Ethiopia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For forty years not a soul will pass that way, neither people nor animals. It will be completely uninhabited.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make Egypt desolate, and it will be surrounded by other desolate nations. Its cities will be empty and desolate for forty years, surrounded by other ruined cities. I will scatter the Egyptians to distant lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But this is what the Sovereign Lord also says: At the end of the forty years I will bring the Egyptians home again from the nations to which they have been scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will restore the prosperity of Egypt and bring its people back to the land of Pathros in southern Egypt from which they came. But Egypt will remain an unimportant, minor kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be the lowliest of all the nations, never again great enough to rise above its neighbors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then Israel will no longer be tempted to trust in Egypt for help. Egypt’s shattered condition will remind Israel of how sinful she was to trust Egypt in earlier days. Then Israel will know that I am the Sovereign Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On April 26, the first day of the new year, during the twenty-seventh year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, the army of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon fought so hard against Tyre that the warriors’ heads were rubbed bare and their shoulders were raw and blistered. Yet Nebuchadnezzar and his army won no plunder to compensate them for all their work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will give the land of Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon. He will carry off its wealth, plundering everything it has so he can pay his army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, I have given him the land of Egypt as a reward for his work, says the Sovereign Lord, because he was working for me when he destroyed Tyre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And the day will come when I will cause the ancient glory of Israel to revive, and then, Ezekiel, your words will be respected. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is another message that came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
for the terrible day is almost here—
    the day of the Lord!
It is a day of clouds and gloom,
    a day of despair for the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword will come against Egypt,
    and those who are slaughtered will cover the ground.
Its wealth will be carried away
    and its foundations destroyed.
The land of Ethiopia will be ravished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ethiopia, Libya, Lydia, all Arabia,
and all their other allies
    will be destroyed in that war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“For this is what the Lord says:
All of Egypt’s allies will fall,
    and the pride of her power will end.
From Migdol to Aswan
    they will be slaughtered by the sword,
    says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt will be desolate,
    surrounded by desolate nations,
and its cities will be in ruins,
    surrounded by other ruined cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And the people of Egypt will know that I am the Lord
    when I have set Egypt on fire
    and destroyed all their allies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At that time I will send swift messengers in ships
    to terrify the complacent Ethiopians.
Great panic will come upon them
    on that day of Egypt’s certain destruction.
Watch for it!
    It is sure to come!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“For this is what the Sovereign Lord says:
By the power of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon,
    I will destroy the hordes of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He and his armies—the most ruthless of all—
    will be sent to demolish the land.
They will make war against Egypt
    until slaughtered Egyptians cover the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will dry up the Nile River
    and sell the land to wicked men.
I will destroy the land of Egypt and everything in it
    by the hands of foreigners.
    I, the Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“This is what the Sovereign Lord says:
I will smash the idols of Egypt
    and the images at Memphis.
There will be no rulers left in Egypt;
    terror will sweep the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will destroy southern Egypt,
    set fire to Zoan,
    and bring judgment against Thebes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will pour out my fury on Pelusium,
    the strongest fortress of Egypt,
and I will stamp out
    the hordes of Thebes.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The young men of Heliopolis and Bubastis will die in battle,
    and the women will be taken away as slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I come to break the proud strength of Egypt,
    it will be a dark day for Tahpanhes, too.
A dark cloud will cover Tahpanhes,
    and its daughters will be led away as captives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And so I will greatly punish Egypt,
    and they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On April 29, during the eleventh year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, I have broken the arm of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. His arm has not been put in a cast so that it may heal. Neither has it been bound up with a splint to make it strong enough to hold a sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I am the enemy of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt! I will break both of his arms—the good arm along with the broken one—and I will make his sword clatter to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will scatter the Egyptians to many lands throughout the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will strengthen the arms of Babylon’s king and put my sword in his hand. But I will break the arms of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and he will lie there mortally wounded, groaning in pain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon, while the arms of Pharaoh fall useless to his sides. And when I put my sword in the hand of Babylon’s king and he brings it against the land of Egypt, Egypt will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, dispersing them throughout the earth. Then they will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On June 21, during the eleventh year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, give this message to Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and all his hordes:
“To whom would you compare your greatness?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are like mighty Assyria,
    which was once like a cedar of Lebanon,
with beautiful branches that cast deep forest shade
    and with its top high among the clouds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Deep springs watered it
    and helped it to grow tall and luxuriant.
The water flowed around it like a river,
    streaming to all the trees nearby.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This great tree towered high,
    higher than all the other trees around it.
It prospered and grew long thick branches
    because of all the water at its roots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The birds nested in its branches,
    and in its shade all the wild animals gave birth.
All the great nations of the world
    lived in its shadow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It was strong and beautiful,
    with wide-spreading branches,
for its roots went deep
    into abundant water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No other cedar in the garden of God
    could rival it.
No cypress had branches to equal it;
    no plane tree had boughs to compare.
No tree in the garden of God
    came close to it in beauty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because I made this tree so beautiful,
    and gave it such magnificent foliage,
it was the envy of all the other trees of Eden,
    the garden of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Because Egypt became proud and arrogant, and because it set itself so high above the others, with its top reaching to the clouds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will hand it over to a mighty nation that will destroy it as its wickedness deserves. I have already discarded it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A foreign army—the terror of the nations—has cut it down and left it fallen on the ground. Its branches are scattered across the mountains and valleys and ravines of the land. All those who lived in its shadow have gone away and left it lying there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The birds roost on its fallen trunk,
    and the wild animals lie among its branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let the tree of no other nation
    proudly exult in its own prosperity,
though it be higher than the clouds
    and it be watered from the depths.
For all are doomed to die,
    to go down to the depths of the earth.
They will land in the pit
    along with everyone else on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: When Assyria went down to the grave, I made the deep springs mourn. I stopped its rivers and dried up its abundant water. I clothed Lebanon in black and caused the trees of the field to wilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made the nations shake with fear at the sound of its fall, for I sent it down to the grave with all the others who descend to the pit. And all the other proud trees of Eden, the most beautiful and the best of Lebanon, the ones whose roots went deep into the water, took comfort to find it there with them in the depths of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its allies, too, were all destroyed and had passed away. They had gone down to the grave—all those nations that had lived in its shade.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “O Egypt, to which of the trees of Eden will you compare your strength and glory? You, too, will be brought down to the depths with all these other nations. You will lie there among the outcasts who have died by the sword. This will be the fate of Pharaoh and all his hordes. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On March 3, during the twelfth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity, this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Son of man, mourn for Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and give him this message:
“You think of yourself as a strong young lion among the nations,
    but you are really just a sea monster,
heaving around in your own rivers,
    stirring up mud with your feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says:
I will send many people
    to catch you in my net
    and haul you out of the water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will leave you stranded on the land to die.
    All the birds of the heavens will land on you,
and the wild animals of the whole earth
    will gorge themselves on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will scatter your flesh on the hills
    and fill the valleys with your bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will drench the earth with your gushing blood
    all the way to the mountains,
    filling the ravines to the brim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I blot you out,
    I will veil the heavens and darken the stars.
I will cover the sun with a cloud,
    and the moon will not give you its light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will darken the bright stars overhead
    and cover your land in darkness.
    I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will disturb many hearts when I bring news of your downfall to distant nations you have never seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, I will shock many lands, and their kings will be terrified at your fate. They will shudder in fear for their lives as I brandish my sword before them on the day of your fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this is what the Sovereign Lord says:
“The sword of the king of Babylon
    will come against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will destroy your hordes with the swords of mighty warriors—
    the terror of the nations.
They will shatter the pride of Egypt,
    and all its hordes will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will destroy all your flocks and herds
    that graze beside the streams.
Never again will people or animals
    muddy those waters with their feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I will let the waters of Egypt become calm again,
    and they will flow as smoothly as olive oil,
    says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And when I destroy Egypt
    and strip you of everything you own
and strike down all your people,
    then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, this is the funeral song
    they will sing for Egypt.
Let all the nations mourn.
    Let them mourn for Egypt and its hordes.
    I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On March 17, during the twelfth year, another message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, weep for the hordes of Egypt and for the other mighty nations. For I will send them down to the world below in company with those who descend to the pit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Say to them,
‘O Egypt, are you lovelier than the other nations?
    No! So go down to the pit and lie there among the outcasts.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians will fall with the many who have died by the sword, for the sword is drawn against them. Egypt and its hordes will be dragged away to their judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Down in the grave mighty leaders will mockingly welcome Egypt and its allies, saying, ‘They have come down; they lie among the outcasts, hordes slaughtered by the sword.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Assyria lies there surrounded by the graves of its army, those who were slaughtered by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their graves are in the depths of the pit, and they are surrounded by their allies. They struck terror in the hearts of people everywhere, but now they have been slaughtered by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Elam lies there surrounded by the graves of all its hordes, those who were slaughtered by the sword. They struck terror in the hearts of people everywhere, but now they have descended as outcasts to the world below. Now they lie in the pit and share the shame of those who have gone before them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have a resting place among the slaughtered, surrounded by the graves of all their hordes. Yes, they terrorized the nations while they lived, but now they lie in shame with others in the pit, all of them outcasts, slaughtered by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Meshech and Tubal are there, surrounded by the graves of all their hordes. They once struck terror in the hearts of people everywhere. But now they are outcasts, all slaughtered by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are not buried in honor like their fallen heroes, who went down to the grave with their weapons—their shields covering their bodies and their swords beneath their heads. Their guilt rests upon them because they brought terror to everyone while they were still alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You too, Egypt, will lie crushed and broken among the outcasts, all slaughtered by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Edom is there with its kings and princes. Mighty as they were, they also lie among those slaughtered by the sword, with the outcasts who have gone down to the pit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All the princes of the north and the Sidonians are there with others who have died. Once a terror, they have been put to shame. They lie there as outcasts with others who were slaughtered by the sword. They share the shame of all who have descended to the pit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When Pharaoh and his entire army arrive, he will take comfort that he is not alone in having his hordes killed, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although I have caused his terror to fall upon all the living, Pharaoh and his hordes will lie there among the outcasts who were slaughtered by the sword. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again a message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, give your people this message: ‘When I bring an army against a country, the people of that land choose one of their own to be a watchman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the watchman sees the enemy coming, he sounds the alarm to warn the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then if those who hear the alarm refuse to take action, it is their own fault if they die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They heard the alarm but ignored it, so the responsibility is theirs. If they had listened to the warning, they could have saved their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the watchman sees the enemy coming and doesn’t sound the alarm to warn the people, he is responsible for their captivity. They will die in their sins, but I will hold the watchman responsible for their deaths.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, son of man, I am making you a watchman for the people of Israel. Therefore, listen to what I say and warn them for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I announce that some wicked people are sure to die and you fail to tell them to change their ways, then they will die in their sins, and I will hold you responsible for their deaths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you warn them to repent and they don’t repent, they will die in their sins, but you will have saved yourself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, give the people of Israel this message: You are saying, ‘Our sins are heavy upon us; we are wasting away! How can we survive?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, I take no pleasure in the death of wicked people. I only want them to turn from their wicked ways so they can live. Turn! Turn from your wickedness, O people of Israel! Why should you die?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, give your people this message: The righteous behavior of righteous people will not save them if they turn to sin, nor will the wicked behavior of wicked people destroy them if they repent and turn from their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I tell righteous people that they will live, but then they sin, expecting their past righteousness to save them, then none of their righteous acts will be remembered. I will destroy them for their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And suppose I tell some wicked people that they will surely die, but then they turn from their sins and do what is just and right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For instance, they might give back a debtor’s security, return what they have stolen, and obey my life-giving laws, no longer doing what is evil. If they do this, then they will surely live and not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: None of their past sins will be brought up again, for they have done what is just and right, and they will surely live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your people are saying, ‘The Lord isn’t doing what’s right,’ but it is they who are not doing what’s right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For again I say, when righteous people turn away from their righteous behavior and turn to evil, they will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if wicked people turn from their wickedness and do what is just and right, they will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O people of Israel, you are saying, ‘The Lord isn’t doing what’s right.’ But I judge each of you according to your deeds.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On January 8, during the twelfth year of our captivity, a survivor from Jerusalem came to me and said, “The city has fallen!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The previous evening the Lord had taken hold of me and given me back my voice. So I was able to speak when this man arrived the next morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, the scattered remnants of Israel living among the ruined cities keep saying, ‘Abraham was only one man, yet he gained possession of the entire land. We are many; surely the land has been given to us as a possession.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So tell these people, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: You eat meat with blood in it, you worship idols, and you murder the innocent. Do you really think the land should be yours?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Murderers! Idolaters! Adulterers! Should the land belong to you?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: As surely as I live, those living in the ruins will die by the sword. And I will send wild animals to eat those living in the open fields. Those hiding in the forts and caves will die of disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will completely destroy the land and demolish her pride. Her arrogant power will come to an end. The mountains of Israel will be so desolate that no one will even travel through them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I have completely destroyed the land because of their detestable sins, then they will know that I am the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, your people talk about you in their houses and whisper about you at the doors. They say to each other, ‘Come on, let’s go hear the prophet tell us what the Lord is saying!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So my people come pretending to be sincere and sit before you. They listen to your words, but they have no intention of doing what you say. Their mouths are full of lustful words, and their hearts seek only after money.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are very entertaining to them, like someone who sings love songs with a beautiful voice or plays fine music on an instrument. They hear what you say, but they don’t act on it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when all these terrible things happen to them—as they certainly will—then they will know a prophet has been among them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, prophesy against the shepherds, the leaders of Israel. Give them this message from the Sovereign Lord: What sorrow awaits you shepherds who feed yourselves instead of your flocks. Shouldn’t shepherds feed their sheep?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You drink the milk, wear the wool, and butcher the best animals, but you let your flocks starve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have not taken care of the weak. You have not tended the sick or bound up the injured. You have not gone looking for those who have wandered away and are lost. Instead, you have ruled them with harshness and cruelty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So my sheep have been scattered without a shepherd, and they are easy prey for any wild animal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have wandered through all the mountains and all the hills, across the face of the earth, yet no one has gone to search for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, you shepherds, hear the word of the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, you abandoned my flock and left them to be attacked by every wild animal. And though you were my shepherds, you didn’t search for my sheep when they were lost. You took care of yourselves and left the sheep to starve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, you shepherds, hear the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I now consider these shepherds my enemies, and I will hold them responsible for what has happened to my flock. I will take away their right to feed the flock, and I will stop them from feeding themselves. I will rescue my flock from their mouths; the sheep will no longer be their prey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I myself will search and find my sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be like a shepherd looking for his scattered flock. I will find my sheep and rescue them from all the places where they were scattered on that dark and cloudy day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring them back home to their own land of Israel from among the peoples and nations. I will feed them on the mountains of Israel and by the rivers and in all the places where people live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, I will give them good pastureland on the high hills of Israel. There they will lie down in pleasant places and feed in the lush pastures of the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself will tend my sheep and give them a place to lie down in peace, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will search for my lost ones who strayed away, and I will bring them safely home again. I will bandage the injured and strengthen the weak. But I will destroy those who are fat and powerful. I will feed them, yes—feed them justice!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And as for you, my flock, this is what the Sovereign Lord says to his people: I will judge between one animal of the flock and another, separating the sheep from the goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t it enough for you to keep the best of the pastures for yourselves? Must you also trample down the rest? Isn’t it enough for you to drink clear water for yourselves? Must you also muddy the rest with your feet?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why must my flock eat what you have trampled down and drink water you have fouled?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will surely judge between the fat sheep and the scrawny sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you fat sheep pushed and butted and crowded my sick and hungry flock until you scattered them to distant lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I will rescue my flock, and they will no longer be abused. I will judge between one animal of the flock and another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will set over them one shepherd, my servant David. He will feed them and be a shepherd to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I, the Lord, will be their God, and my servant David will be a prince among my people. I, the Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will make a covenant of peace with my people and drive away the dangerous animals from the land. Then they will be able to camp safely in the wildest places and sleep in the woods without fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bless my people and their homes around my holy hill. And in the proper season I will send the showers they need. There will be showers of blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator
