verses.text: The orchards and fields of my people will yield bumper crops, and everyone will live in safety. When I have broken their chains of slavery and rescued them from those who enslaved them, then they will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will no longer be prey for other nations, and wild animals will no longer devour them. They will live in safety, and no one will frighten them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And I will make their land famous for its crops, so my people will never again suffer from famines or the insults of foreign nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, they will know that I, the Lord their God, am with them. And they will know that they, the people of Israel, are my people, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are my flock, the sheep of my pasture. You are my people, and I am your God. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again a message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face Mount Seir, and prophesy against its people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give them this message from the Sovereign Lord:
“I am your enemy, O Mount Seir,
    and I will raise my fist against you
    to destroy you completely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will demolish your cities
    and make you desolate.
Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your eternal hatred for the people of Israel led you to butcher them when they were helpless, when I had already punished them for all their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, since you show no distaste for blood, I will give you a bloodbath of your own. Your turn has come!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make Mount Seir utterly desolate, killing off all who try to escape and any who return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will fill your mountains with the dead. Your hills, your valleys, and your ravines will be filled with people slaughtered by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make you desolate forever. Your cities will never be rebuilt. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For you said, ‘The lands of Israel and Judah will be ours. We will take possession of them. What do we care that the Lord is there!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, as surely as I live, says the Sovereign Lord, I will pay back your angry deeds with my own. I will punish you for all your acts of anger, envy, and hatred. And I will make myself known to Israel by what I do to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will know that I, the Lord, have heard every contemptuous word you spoke against the mountains of Israel. For you said, ‘They are desolate; they have been given to us as food to eat!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In saying that, you boasted proudly against me, and I have heard it all!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The whole world will rejoice when I make you desolate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You rejoiced at the desolation of Israel’s territory. Now I will rejoice at yours! You will be wiped out, you people of Mount Seir and all who live in Edom! Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, prophesy to Israel’s mountains. Give them this message: O mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Your enemies have taunted you, saying, ‘Aha! Now the ancient heights belong to us!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, son of man, give the mountains of Israel this message from the Sovereign Lord: Your enemies have attacked you from all directions, making you the property of many nations and the object of much mocking and slander.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, O mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Sovereign Lord. He speaks to the hills and mountains, ravines and valleys, and to ruined wastes and long-deserted cities that have been destroyed and mocked by the surrounding nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: My jealous anger burns against these nations, especially Edom, because they have shown utter contempt for me by gleefully taking my land for themselves as plunder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, prophesy to the hills and mountains, the ravines and valleys of Israel. This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I am furious that you have suffered shame before the surrounding nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I have taken a solemn oath that those nations will soon have their own shame to endure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But the mountains of Israel will produce heavy crops of fruit for my people—for they will be coming home again soon!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, I care about you, and I will pay attention to you. Your ground will be plowed and your crops planted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will greatly increase the population of Israel, and the ruined cities will be rebuilt and filled with people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will increase not only the people, but also your animals. O mountains of Israel, I will bring people to live on you once again. I will make you even more prosperous than you were before. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will cause my people to walk on you once again, and you will be their territory. You will never again rob them of their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The other nations taunt you, saying, ‘Israel is a land that devours its own people and robs them of their children!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you will never again devour your people or rob them of their children, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will not let you hear those other nations insult you, and you will no longer be mocked by them. You will not be a land that causes its nation to fall, says the Sovereign Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this further message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, when the people of Israel were living in their own land, they defiled it by the evil way they lived. To me their conduct was as unclean as a woman’s menstrual cloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They polluted the land with murder and the worship of idols, so I poured out my fury on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I scattered them to many lands to punish them for the evil way they had lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they were scattered among the nations, they brought shame on my holy name. For the nations said, ‘These are the people of the Lord, but he couldn’t keep them safe in his own land!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I was concerned for my holy name, on which my people brought shame among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, give the people of Israel this message from the Sovereign Lord: I am bringing you back, but not because you deserve it. I am doing it to protect my holy name, on which you brought shame while you were scattered among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will show how holy my great name is—the name on which you brought shame among the nations. And when I reveal my holiness through you before their very eyes, says the Sovereign Lord, then the nations will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I will gather you up from all the nations and bring you home again to your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then I will sprinkle clean water on you, and you will be clean. Your filth will be washed away, and you will no longer worship idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will give you a new heart, and I will put a new spirit in you. I will take out your stony, stubborn heart and give you a tender, responsive heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will put my Spirit in you so that you will follow my decrees and be careful to obey my regulations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And you will live in Israel, the land I gave your ancestors long ago. You will be my people, and I will be your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will cleanse you of your filthy behavior. I will give you good crops of grain, and I will send no more famines on the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give you great harvests from your fruit trees and fields, and never again will the surrounding nations be able to scoff at your land for its famines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will remember your past sins and despise yourselves for all the detestable things you did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But remember, says the Sovereign Lord, I am not doing this because you deserve it. O my people of Israel, you should be utterly ashamed of all you have done!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: When I cleanse you from your sins, I will repopulate your cities, and the ruins will be rebuilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fields that used to lie empty and desolate in plain view of everyone will again be farmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when I bring you back, people will say, ‘This former wasteland is now like the Garden of Eden! The abandoned and ruined cities now have strong walls and are filled with people!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the surrounding nations that survive will know that I, the Lord, have rebuilt the ruins and replanted the wasteland. For I, the Lord, have spoken, and I will do what I say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I am ready to hear Israel’s prayers and to increase their numbers like a flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will be as numerous as the sacred flocks that fill Jerusalem’s streets at the time of her festivals. The ruined cities will be crowded with people once more, and everyone will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord took hold of me, and I was carried away by the Spirit of the Lord to a valley filled with bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He led me all around among the bones that covered the valley floor. They were scattered everywhere across the ground and were completely dried out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he asked me, “Son of man, can these bones become living people again?”
“O Sovereign Lord,” I replied, “you alone know the answer to that.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, “Speak a prophetic message to these bones and say, ‘Dry bones, listen to the word of the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Look! I am going to put breath into you and make you live again!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will put flesh and muscles on you and cover you with skin. I will put breath into you, and you will come to life. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I spoke this message, just as he told me. Suddenly as I spoke, there was a rattling noise all across the valley. The bones of each body came together and attached themselves as complete skeletons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then as I watched, muscles and flesh formed over the bones. Then skin formed to cover their bodies, but they still had no breath in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, “Speak a prophetic message to the winds, son of man. Speak a prophetic message and say, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: Come, O breath, from the four winds! Breathe into these dead bodies so they may live again.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I spoke the message as he commanded me, and breath came into their bodies. They all came to life and stood up on their feet—a great army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, “Son of man, these bones represent the people of Israel. They are saying, ‘We have become old, dry bones—all hope is gone. Our nation is finished.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, prophesy to them and say, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: O my people, I will open your graves of exile and cause you to rise again. Then I will bring you back to the land of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this happens, O my people, you will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will put my Spirit in you, and you will live again and return home to your own land. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have spoken, and I have done what I said. Yes, the Lord has spoken!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again a message came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, take a piece of wood and carve on it these words: ‘This represents Judah and its allied tribes.’ Then take another piece and carve these words on it: ‘This represents Ephraim and the northern tribes of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now hold them together in your hand as if they were one piece of wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your people ask you what your actions mean,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: say to them, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will take Ephraim and the northern tribes and join them to Judah. I will make them one piece of wood in my hand.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then hold out the pieces of wood you have inscribed, so the people can see them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And give them this message from the Sovereign Lord: I will gather the people of Israel from among the nations. I will bring them home to their own land from the places where they have been scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will unify them into one nation on the mountains of Israel. One king will rule them all; no longer will they be divided into two nations or into two kingdoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will never again pollute themselves with their idols and vile images and rebellion, for I will save them from their sinful apostasy. I will cleanse them. Then they will truly be my people, and I will be their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My servant David will be their king, and they will have only one shepherd. They will obey my regulations and be careful to keep my decrees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will live in the land I gave my servant Jacob, the land where their ancestors lived. They and their children and their grandchildren after them will live there forever, generation after generation. And my servant David will be their prince forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will make a covenant of peace with them, an everlasting covenant. I will give them their land and increase their numbers, and I will put my Temple among them forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make my home among them. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when my Temple is among them forever, the nations will know that I am the Lord, who makes Israel holy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is another message that came to me from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, turn and face Gog of the land of Magog, the prince who rules over the nations of Meshech and Tubal, and prophesy against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give him this message from the Sovereign Lord: Gog, I am your enemy!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will turn you around and put hooks in your jaws to lead you out with your whole army—your horses and charioteers in full armor and a great horde armed with shields and swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Persia, Ethiopia, and Libya will join you, too, with all their weapons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gomer and all its armies will also join you, along with the armies of Beth-togarmah from the distant north, and many others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get ready; be prepared! Keep all the armies around you mobilized, and take command of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A long time from now you will be called into action. In the distant future you will swoop down on the land of Israel, which will be enjoying peace after recovering from war and after its people have returned from many lands to the mountains of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and all your allies—a vast and awesome army—will roll down on them like a storm and cover the land like a cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: At that time evil thoughts will come to your mind, and you will devise a wicked scheme.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will say, ‘Israel is an unprotected land filled with unwalled villages! I will march against her and destroy these people who live in such confidence!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will go to those formerly desolate cities that are now filled with people who have returned from exile in many nations. I will capture vast amounts of plunder, for the people are rich with livestock and other possessions now. They think the whole world revolves around them!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Sheba and Dedan and the merchants of Tarshish will ask, ‘Do you really think the armies you have gathered can rob them of silver and gold? Do you think you can drive away their livestock and seize their goods and carry off plunder?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, son of man, prophesy against Gog. Give him this message from the Sovereign Lord: When my people are living in peace in their land, then you will rouse yourself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will come from your homeland in the distant north with your vast cavalry and your mighty army,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you will attack my people Israel, covering their land like a cloud. At that time in the distant future, I will bring you against my land as everyone watches, and my holiness will be displayed by what happens to you, Gog. Then all the nations will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord asks: Are you the one I was talking about long ago, when I announced through Israel’s prophets that in the future I would bring you against my people?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But this is what the Sovereign Lord says: When Gog invades the land of Israel, my fury will boil over!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In my jealousy and blazing anger, I promise a mighty shaking in the land of Israel on that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All living things—the fish in the sea, the birds of the sky, the animals of the field, the small animals that scurry along the ground, and all the people on earth—will quake in terror at my presence. Mountains will be thrown down; cliffs will crumble; walls will fall to the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will summon the sword against you on all the hills of Israel, says the Sovereign Lord. Your men will turn their swords against each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will punish you and your armies with disease and bloodshed; I will send torrential rain, hailstones, fire, and burning sulfur!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, I will show my greatness and holiness, and I will make myself known to all the nations of the world. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, prophesy against Gog. Give him this message from the Sovereign Lord: I am your enemy, O Gog, ruler of the nations of Meshech and Tubal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will turn you around and drive you toward the mountains of Israel, bringing you from the distant north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will knock the bow from your left hand and the arrows from your right hand, and I will leave you helpless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and your army and your allies will all die on the mountains. I will feed you to the vultures and wild animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will fall in the open fields, for I have spoken, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will rain down fire on Magog and on all your allies who live safely on the coasts. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In this way, I will make known my holy name among my people of Israel. I will not let anyone bring shame on it. And the nations, too, will know that I am the Lord, the Holy One of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day of judgment will come, says the Sovereign Lord. Everything will happen just as I have declared it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then the people in the towns of Israel will go out and pick up your small and large shields, bows and arrows, javelins and spears, and they will use them for fuel. There will be enough to last them seven years!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They won’t need to cut wood from the fields or forests, for these weapons will give them all the fuel they need. They will plunder those who planned to plunder them, and they will rob those who planned to rob them, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And I will make a vast graveyard for Gog and his hordes in the Valley of the Travelers, east of the Dead Sea. It will block the way of those who travel there, and they will change the name of the place to the Valley of Gog’s Hordes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will take seven months for the people of Israel to bury the bodies and cleanse the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone in Israel will help, for it will be a glorious victory for Israel when I demonstrate my glory on that day, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “After seven months, teams of men will be appointed to search the land for skeletons to bury, so the land will be made clean again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever bones are found, a marker will be set up so the burial crews will take them to be buried in the Valley of Gog’s Hordes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (There will be a town there named Hamonah, which means ‘horde.’) And so the land will finally be cleansed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, son of man, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Call all the birds and wild animals. Say to them: Gather together for my great sacrificial feast. Come from far and near to the mountains of Israel, and there eat flesh and drink blood!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eat the flesh of mighty men and drink the blood of princes as though they were rams, lambs, goats, and bulls—all fattened animals from Bashan!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gorge yourselves with flesh until you are glutted; drink blood until you are drunk. This is the sacrificial feast I have prepared for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Feast at my banquet table—feast on horses and charioteers, on mighty men and all kinds of valiant warriors, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In this way, I will demonstrate my glory to the nations. Everyone will see the punishment I have inflicted on them and the power of my fist when I strike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And from that time on the people of Israel will know that I am the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The nations will then know why Israel was sent away to exile—it was punishment for sin, for they were unfaithful to their God. Therefore, I turned away from them and let their enemies destroy them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I turned my face away and punished them because of their defilement and their sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So now, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I will end the captivity of my people; I will have mercy on all Israel, for I jealously guard my holy reputation!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will accept responsibility for their past shame and unfaithfulness after they come home to live in peace in their own land, with no one to bother them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I bring them home from the lands of their enemies, I will display my holiness among them for all the nations to see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then my people will know that I am the Lord their God, because I sent them away to exile and brought them home again. I will leave none of my people behind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will never again turn my face from them, for I will pour out my Spirit upon the people of Israel. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On April 28, during the twenty-fifth year of our captivity—fourteen years after the fall of Jerusalem—the Lord took hold of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In a vision from God he took me to the land of Israel and set me down on a very high mountain. From there I could see toward the south what appeared to be a city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he brought me nearer, I saw a man whose face shone like bronze standing beside a gateway entrance. He was holding in his hand a linen measuring cord and a measuring rod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, “Son of man, watch and listen. Pay close attention to everything I show you. You have been brought here so I can show you many things. Then you will return to the people of Israel and tell them everything you have seen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I could see a wall completely surrounding the Temple area. The man took a measuring rod that was 10 1⁄2 feet long and measured the wall, and the wall was 10 1⁄2 feet thick and 10 1⁄2 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went over to the eastern gateway. He climbed the steps and measured the threshold of the gateway; it was 10 1⁄2 feet front to back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were guard alcoves on each side built into the gateway passage. Each of these alcoves was 10 1⁄2 feet square, with a distance between them of 8 3⁄4 feet along the passage wall. The gateway’s inner threshold, which led to the entry room at the inner end of the gateway passage, was 10 1⁄2 feet front to back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also measured the entry room of the gateway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was 14 feet across, with supporting columns 3 1⁄2 feet thick. This entry room was at the inner end of the gateway structure, facing toward the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were three guard alcoves on each side of the gateway passage. Each had the same measurements, and the dividing walls separating them were also identical.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man measured the gateway entrance, which was 17 1⁄2 feet wide at the opening and 22 3⁄4 feet wide in the gateway passage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In front of each of the guard alcoves was a 21-inch curb. The alcoves themselves were 10 1⁄2 feet on each side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he measured the entire width of the gateway, measuring the distance between the back walls of facing guard alcoves; this distance was 43 3⁄4 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He measured the dividing walls all along the inside of the gateway up to the entry room of the gateway; this distance was 105 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The full length of the gateway passage was 87 1⁄2 feet from one end to the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were recessed windows that narrowed inward through the walls of the guard alcoves and their dividing walls. There were also windows in the entry room. The surfaces of the dividing walls were decorated with carved palm trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man brought me through the gateway into the outer courtyard of the Temple. A stone pavement ran along the walls of the courtyard, and thirty rooms were built against the walls, opening onto the pavement.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This pavement flanked the gates and extended out from the walls into the courtyard the same distance as the gateway entrance. This was the lower pavement.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man measured across the Temple’s outer courtyard between the outer and inner gateways; the distance was 175 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man measured the gateway on the north just like the one on the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here, too, there were three guard alcoves on each side, with dividing walls and an entry room. All the measurements matched those of the east gateway. The gateway passage was 87 1⁄2 feet long and 43 3⁄4 feet wide between the back walls of facing guard alcoves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The windows, the entry room, and the palm tree decorations were identical to those in the east gateway. There were seven steps leading up to the gateway entrance, and the entry room was at the inner end of the gateway passage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here on the north side, just as on the east, there was another gateway leading to the Temple’s inner courtyard directly opposite this outer gateway. The distance between the two gateways was 175 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man took me around to the south gateway and measured its various parts, and they were exactly the same as in the others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It had windows along the walls as the others did, and there was an entry room where the gateway passage opened into the outer courtyard. And like the others, the gateway passage was 87 1⁄2 feet long and 43 3⁄4 feet wide between the back walls of facing guard alcoves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This gateway also had a stairway of seven steps leading up to it, and an entry room at the inner end, and palm tree decorations along the dividing walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And here again, directly opposite the outer gateway, was another gateway that led into the inner courtyard. The distance between the two gateways was 175 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man took me to the south gateway leading into the inner courtyard. He measured it, and it had the same measurements as the other gateways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its guard alcoves, dividing walls, and entry room were the same size as those in the others. It also had windows along its walls and in the entry room. And like the others, the gateway passage was 87 1⁄2 feet long and 43 3⁄4 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The entry rooms of the gateways leading into the inner courtyard were 14 feet across and 43 3⁄4 feet wide.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entry room to the south gateway faced into the outer courtyard. It had palm tree decorations on its columns, and there were eight steps leading to its entrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he took me to the east gateway leading to the inner courtyard. He measured it, and it had the same measurements as the other gateways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its guard alcoves, dividing walls, and entry room were the same size as those of the others, and there were windows along the walls and in the entry room. The gateway passage measured 87 1⁄2 feet long and 43 3⁄4 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its entry room faced into the outer courtyard. It had palm tree decorations on its columns, and there were eight steps leading to its entrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he took me around to the north gateway leading to the inner courtyard. He measured it, and it had the same measurements as the other gateways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The guard alcoves, dividing walls, and entry room of this gateway had the same measurements as in the others and the same window arrangements. The gateway passage measured 87 1⁄2 feet long and 43 3⁄4 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its entry room faced into the outer courtyard, and it had palm tree decorations on the columns. There were eight steps leading to its entrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A door led from the entry room of one of the inner gateways into a side room, where the meat for sacrifices was washed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On each side of this entry room were two tables, where the sacrificial animals were slaughtered for the burnt offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Outside the entry room, on each side of the stairs going up to the north entrance, were two more tables.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there were eight tables in all—four inside and four outside—where the sacrifices were cut up and prepared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were also four tables of finished stone for preparation of the burnt offerings, each 31 1⁄2 inches square and 21 inches high. On these tables were placed the butchering knives and other implements for slaughtering the sacrificial animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were hooks, each 3 inches long, fastened all around the foyer walls. The sacrificial meat was laid on the tables.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Inside the inner courtyard were two rooms, one beside the north gateway, facing south, and the other beside the south gateway, facing north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the man said to me, “The room beside the north inner gate is for the priests who supervise the Temple maintenance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The room beside the south inner gate is for the priests in charge of the altar—the descendants of Zadok—for they alone of all the Levites may approach the Lord to minister to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man measured the inner courtyard, and it was a square, 175 feet wide and 175 feet across. The altar stood in the courtyard in front of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought me to the entry room of the Temple. He measured the walls on either side of the opening to the entry room, and they were 8 3⁄4 feet thick. The entrance itself was 24 1⁄2 feet wide, and the walls on each side of the entrance were an additional 5 1⁄4 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entry room was 35 feet wide and 21 feet deep. There were ten steps leading up to it, with a column on each side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that, the man brought me into the sanctuary of the Temple. He measured the walls on either side of its doorway, and they were 10 1⁄2 feet thick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The doorway was 17 1⁄2 feet wide, and the walls on each side of it were 8 3⁄4 feet long. The sanctuary itself was 70 feet long and 35 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went beyond the sanctuary into the inner room. He measured the walls on either side of its entrance, and they were 3 1⁄2 feet thick. The entrance was 10 1⁄2 feet wide, and the walls on each side of the entrance were 12 1⁄4 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The inner room of the sanctuary was 35 feet long and 35 feet wide. “This,” he told me, “is the Most Holy Place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he measured the wall of the Temple, and it was 10 1⁄2 feet thick. There was a row of rooms along the outside wall; each room was 7 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These side rooms were built in three levels, one above the other, with thirty rooms on each level. The supports for these side rooms rested on exterior ledges on the Temple wall; they did not extend into the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each level was wider than the one below it, corresponding to the narrowing of the Temple wall as it rose higher. A stairway led up from the bottom level through the middle level to the top level.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I saw that the Temple was built on a terrace, which provided a foundation for the side rooms. This terrace was 10 1⁄2 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The outer wall of the Temple’s side rooms was 8 3⁄4 feet thick. This left an open area between these side rooms
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the row of rooms along the outer wall of the inner courtyard. This open area was 35 feet wide, and it went all the way around the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two doors opened from the side rooms into the terrace yard, which was 8 3⁄4 feet wide. One door faced north and the other south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A large building stood on the west, facing the Temple courtyard. It was 122 1⁄2 feet wide and 157 1⁄2 feet long, and its walls were 8 3⁄4 feet thick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man measured the Temple, and it was 175 feet long. The courtyard around the building, including its walls, was an additional 175 feet in length.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The inner courtyard to the east of the Temple was also 175 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The building to the west, including its two walls, was also 175 feet wide.
The sanctuary, the inner room, and the entry room of the Temple
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: were all paneled with wood, as were the frames of the recessed windows. The inner walls of the Temple were paneled with wood above and below the windows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The space above the door leading into the inner room, and its walls inside and out, were also paneled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the walls were decorated with carvings of cherubim, each with two faces, and there was a carving of a palm tree between each of the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One face—that of a man—looked toward the palm tree on one side. The other face—that of a young lion—looked toward the palm tree on the other side. The figures were carved all along the inside of the Temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from the floor to the top of the walls, including the outer wall of the sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were square columns at the entrance to the sanctuary, and the ones at the entrance of the Most Holy Place were similar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was an altar made of wood, 5 1⁄4 feet high and 3 1⁄2 feet across. Its corners, base, and sides were all made of wood. “This,” the man told me, “is the table that stands in the Lord’s presence.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both the sanctuary and the Most Holy Place had double doorways,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: each with two swinging doors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The doors leading into the sanctuary were decorated with carved cherubim and palm trees, just as on the walls. And there was a wooden roof at the front of the entry room to the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On both sides of the entry room were recessed windows decorated with carved palm trees. The side rooms along the outside wall also had roofs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man led me out of the Temple courtyard by way of the north gateway. We entered the outer courtyard and came to a group of rooms against the north wall of the inner courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This structure, whose entrance opened toward the north, was 175 feet long and 87 1⁄2 feet wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One block of rooms overlooked the 35-foot width of the inner courtyard. Another block of rooms looked out onto the pavement of the outer courtyard. The two blocks were built three levels high and stood across from each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Between the two blocks of rooms ran a walkway 17 1⁄2 feet wide. It extended the entire 175 feet of the complex, and all the doors faced north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of the two upper levels of rooms was narrower than the one beneath it because the upper levels had to allow space for walkways in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since there were three levels and they did not have supporting columns as in the courtyards, each of the upper levels was set back from the level beneath it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was an outer wall that separated the rooms from the outer courtyard; it was 87 1⁄2 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This wall added length to the outer block of rooms, which extended for only 87 1⁄2 feet, while the inner block—the rooms toward the Temple—extended for 175 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was an eastern entrance from the outer courtyard to these rooms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the south side of the Temple there were two blocks of rooms just south of the inner courtyard between the Temple and the outer courtyard. These rooms were arranged just like the rooms on the north.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a walkway between the two blocks of rooms just like the complex on the north side of the Temple. This complex of rooms was the same length and width as the other one, and it had the same entrances and doors. The dimensions of each were identical.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there was an entrance in the wall facing the doors of the inner block of rooms, and another on the east at the end of the interior walkway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man told me, “These rooms that overlook the Temple from the north and south are holy. Here the priests who offer sacrifices to the Lord will eat the most holy offerings. And because these rooms are holy, they will be used to store the sacred offerings—the grain offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the priests leave the sanctuary, they must not go directly to the outer courtyard. They must first take off the clothes they wore while ministering, because these clothes are holy. They must put on other clothes before entering the parts of the building complex open to the public.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the man had finished measuring the inside of the Temple area, he led me out through the east gateway to measure the entire perimeter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He measured the east side with his measuring rod, and it was 875 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he measured the north side, and it was also 875 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The south side was also 875 feet,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the west side was also 875 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the area was 875 feet on each side with a wall all around it to separate what was holy from what was common.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the man brought me back around to the east gateway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly, the glory of the God of Israel appeared from the east. The sound of his coming was like the roar of rushing waters, and the whole landscape shone with his glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This vision was just like the others I had seen, first by the Kebar River and then when he came to destroy Jerusalem. I fell face down on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the glory of the Lord came into the Temple through the east gateway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Spirit took me up and brought me into the inner courtyard, and the glory of the Lord filled the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I heard someone speaking to me from within the Temple, while the man who had been measuring stood beside me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to me, “Son of man, this is the place of my throne and the place where I will rest my feet. I will live here forever among the people of Israel. They and their kings will not defile my holy name any longer by their adulterous worship of other gods or by honoring the relics of their kings who have died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They put their idol altars right next to mine with only a wall between them and me. They defiled my holy name by such detestable sin, so I consumed them in my anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now let them stop worshiping other gods and honoring the relics of their kings, and I will live among them forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Son of man, describe to the people of Israel the Temple I have shown you, so they will be ashamed of all their sins. Let them study its plan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they will be ashamed of what they have done. Describe to them all the specifications of the Temple—including its entrances and exits—and everything else about it. Tell them about its decrees and laws. Write down all these specifications and decrees as they watch so they will be sure to remember and follow them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this is the basic law of the Temple: absolute holiness! The entire top of the mountain where the Temple is built is holy. Yes, this is the basic law of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These are the measurements of the altar: There is a gutter all around the altar 21 inches deep and 21 inches wide, with a curb 9 inches wide around its edge. And this is the height of the altar:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the gutter the altar rises 3 1⁄2 feet to a lower ledge that surrounds the altar and is 21 inches wide. From the lower ledge the altar rises 7 feet to the upper ledge that is also 21 inches wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The top of the altar, the hearth, rises another 7 feet higher, with a horn rising up from each of the four corners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The top of the altar is square, measuring 21 feet by 21 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The upper ledge also forms a square, measuring 24 1⁄2 feet by 24 1⁄2 feet, with a 21-inch gutter and a 10 1⁄2-inch curb all around the edge. There are steps going up the east side of the altar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, “Son of man, this is what the Sovereign Lord says: These will be the regulations for the burning of offerings and the sprinkling of blood when the altar is built.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time, the Levitical priests of the family of Zadok, who minister before me, are to be given a young bull for a sin offering, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will take some of its blood and smear it on the four horns of the altar, the four corners of the upper ledge, and the curb that runs around that ledge. This will cleanse and make atonement for the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take the young bull for the sin offering and burn it at the appointed place outside the Temple area.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “On the second day, sacrifice as a sin offering a young male goat that has no physical defects. Then cleanse and make atonement for the altar again, just as you did with the young bull.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you have finished the cleansing ceremony, offer another young bull that has no defects and a perfect ram from the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to present them to the Lord, and the priests are to sprinkle salt on them and offer them as a burnt offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Every day for seven days a male goat, a young bull, and a ram from the flock will be sacrificed as a sin offering. None of these animals may have physical defects of any kind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do this each day for seven days to cleanse and make atonement for the altar, thus setting it apart for holy use.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the eighth day, and on each day afterward, the priests will sacrifice on the altar the burnt offerings and peace offerings of the people. Then I will accept you. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man brought me back to the east gateway in the outer wall of the Temple area, but it was closed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to me, “This gate must remain closed; it will never again be opened. No one will ever open it and pass through, for the Lord, the God of Israel, has entered here. Therefore, it must always remain shut.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only the prince himself may sit inside this gateway to feast in the Lord’s presence. But he may come and go only through the entry room of the gateway.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man brought me through the north gateway to the front of the Temple. I looked and saw that the glory of the Lord filled the Temple of the Lord, and I fell face down on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to me, “Son of man, take careful notice. Use your eyes and ears, and listen to everything I tell you about the regulations concerning the Lord’s Temple. Take careful note of the procedures for using the Temple’s entrances and exits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And give these rebels, the people of Israel, this message from the Sovereign Lord: O people of Israel, enough of your detestable sins!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have brought uncircumcised foreigners into my sanctuary—people who have no heart for God. In this way, you defiled my Temple even as you offered me my food, the fat and blood of sacrifices. In addition to all your other detestable sins, you have broken my covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead of safeguarding my sacred rituals, you have hired foreigners to take charge of my sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So this is what the Sovereign Lord says: No foreigners, including those who live among the people of Israel, will enter my sanctuary if they have not been circumcised and have not surrendered themselves to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the men of the tribe of Levi who abandoned me when Israel strayed away from me to worship idols must bear the consequences of their unfaithfulness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They may still be Temple guards and gatekeepers, and they may slaughter the animals brought for burnt offerings and be present to help the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they encouraged my people to worship idols, causing Israel to fall into deep sin. So I have taken a solemn oath that they must bear the consequences for their sins, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They may not approach me to minister as priests. They may not touch any of my holy things or the holy offerings, for they must bear the shame of all the detestable sins they have committed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to serve as the Temple caretakers, taking charge of the maintenance work and performing general duties.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “However, the Levitical priests of the family of Zadok continued to minister faithfully in the Temple when Israel abandoned me for idols. These men will serve as my ministers. They will stand in my presence and offer the fat and blood of the sacrifices, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They alone will enter my sanctuary and approach my table to serve me. They will fulfill all my requirements.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When they enter the gateway to the inner courtyard, they must wear only linen clothing. They must wear no wool while on duty in the inner courtyard or in the Temple itself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They must wear linen turbans and linen undergarments. They must not wear anything that would cause them to perspire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they return to the outer courtyard where the people are, they must take off the clothes they wear while ministering to me. They must leave them in the sacred rooms and put on other clothes so they do not endanger anyone by transmitting holiness to them through this clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They must neither shave their heads nor let their hair grow too long. Instead, they must trim it regularly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests must not drink wine before entering the inner courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They may choose their wives only from among the virgins of Israel or the widows of the priests. They may not marry other widows or divorced women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will teach my people the difference between what is holy and what is common, what is ceremonially clean and unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They will serve as judges to resolve any disagreements among my people. Their decisions must be based on my regulations. And the priests themselves must obey my instructions and decrees at all the sacred festivals, and see to it that the Sabbaths are set apart as holy days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “A priest must not defile himself by being in the presence of a dead person unless it is his father, mother, child, brother, or unmarried sister. In such cases it is permitted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even then, he can return to his Temple duties only after being ceremonially cleansed and then waiting for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first day he returns to work and enters the inner courtyard and the sanctuary, he must offer a sin offering for himself, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The priests will not have any property or possession of land, for I alone am their special possession.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their food will come from the gifts and sacrifices brought to the Temple by the people—the grain offerings, the sin offerings, and the guilt offerings. Whatever anyone sets apart for the Lord will belong to the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first of the ripe fruits and all the gifts brought to the Lord will go to the priests. The first batch of dough must also be given to the priests so the Lord will bless your homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests may not eat meat from any bird or animal that dies a natural death or that dies after being attacked by another animal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you divide the land among the tribes of Israel, you must set aside a section for the Lord as his holy portion. This piece of land will be 8 1⁄3 miles long and 6 2⁄3 miles wide. The entire area will be holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A section of this land, measuring 875 feet by 875 feet, will be set aside for the Temple. An additional strip of land 87 1⁄2 feet wide is to be left empty all around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Within the larger sacred area, measure out a portion of land 8 1⁄3 miles long and 3 1⁄3 miles wide. Within it the sanctuary of the Most Holy Place will be located.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This area will be holy, set aside for the priests who minister to the Lord in the sanctuary. They will use it for their homes, and my Temple will be located within it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The strip of sacred land next to it, also 8 1⁄3 miles long and 3 1⁄3 miles wide, will be a living area for the Levites who work at the Temple. It will be their possession and a place for their towns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Adjacent to the larger sacred area will be a section of land 8 1⁄3 miles long and 1 2⁄3 miles wide. This will be set aside for a city where anyone in Israel can live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Two special sections of land will be set apart for the prince. One section will share a border with the east side of the sacred lands and city, and the second section will share a border on the west side. Then the far eastern and western borders of the prince’s lands will line up with the eastern and western boundaries of the tribal areas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These sections of land will be the prince’s allotment. Then my princes will no longer oppress and rob my people; they will assign the rest of the land to the people, giving an allotment to each tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For this is what the Sovereign Lord says: Enough, you princes of Israel! Stop your violence and oppression and do what is just and right. Quit robbing and cheating my people out of their land. Stop expelling them from their homes, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Use only honest weights and scales and honest measures, both dry and liquid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The homer will be your standard unit for measuring volume. The ephah and the bath will each measure one-tenth of a homer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The standard unit for weight will be the silver shekel. One shekel will consist of twenty gerahs, and sixty shekels will be equal to one mina.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You must give this tax to the prince: one bushel of wheat or barley for every 60 you harvest,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: one percent of your olive oil,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and one sheep or goat for every 200 in your flocks in Israel. These will be the grain offerings, burnt offerings, and peace offerings that will make atonement for the people who bring them, says the Sovereign Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Israel must join in bringing these offerings to the prince.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prince will be required to provide offerings that are given at the religious festivals, the new moon celebrations, the Sabbath days, and all other similar occasions. He will provide the sin offerings, burnt offerings, grain offerings, liquid offerings, and peace offerings to purify the people of Israel, making them right with the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: In early spring, on the first day of each new year, sacrifice a young bull with no defects to purify the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest will take blood from this sin offering and put it on the doorposts of the Temple, the four corners of the upper ledge of the altar, and the gateposts at the entrance to the inner courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do this also on the seventh day of the new year for anyone who has sinned through error or ignorance. In this way, you will purify the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “On the fourteenth day of the first month, you must celebrate the Passover. This festival will last for seven days. The bread you eat during that time must be made without yeast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day of Passover the prince will provide a young bull as a sin offering for himself and the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On each of the seven days of the feast he will prepare a burnt offering to the Lord, consisting of seven young bulls and seven rams without defects. A male goat will also be given each day for a sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prince will provide a basket of flour as a grain offering and a gallon of olive oil with each young bull and ram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “During the seven days of the Festival of Shelters, which occurs every year in early autumn, the prince will provide these same sacrifices for the sin offering, the burnt offering, and the grain offering, along with the required olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: The east gateway of the inner courtyard will be closed during the six workdays each week, but it will be open on Sabbath days and the days of new moon celebrations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prince will enter the entry room of the gateway from the outside. Then he will stand by the gatepost while the priest offers his burnt offering and peace offering. He will bow down in worship inside the gateway passage and then go back out the way he came. The gateway will not be closed until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The common people will bow down and worship the Lord in front of this gateway on Sabbath days and the days of new moon celebrations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Each Sabbath day the prince will present to the Lord a burnt offering of six lambs and one ram, all with no defects.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will present a grain offering of a basket of choice flour to go with the ram and whatever amount of flour he chooses to go with each lamb, and he is to offer one gallon of olive oil for each basket of flour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the new moon celebrations, he will bring one young bull, six lambs, and one ram, all with no defects.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the young bull he must bring a basket of choice flour for a grain offering. With the ram he must bring another basket of flour. And with each lamb he is to bring whatever amount of flour he chooses to give. With each basket of flour he must offer one gallon of olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The prince must enter the gateway through the entry room, and he must leave the same way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the people come in through the north gateway to worship the Lord during the religious festivals, they must leave by the south gateway. And those who entered through the south gateway must leave by the north gateway. They must never leave by the same gateway they came in, but must always use the opposite gateway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prince will enter and leave with the people on these occasions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So at the special feasts and sacred festivals, the grain offering will be a basket of choice flour with each young bull, another basket of flour with each ram, and as much flour as the worshiper chooses to give with each lamb. Give one gallon of olive oil with each basket of flour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the prince offers a voluntary burnt offering or peace offering to the Lord, the east gateway to the inner courtyard will be opened for him, and he will offer his sacrifices as he does on Sabbath days. Then he will leave, and the gateway will be shut behind him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Each morning you must sacrifice a one-year-old lamb with no defects as a burnt offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the lamb, a grain offering must also be given to the Lord—about three quarts of flour with a third of a gallon of olive oil to moisten the choice flour. This will be a permanent law for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lamb, the grain offering, and the olive oil must be given as a daily sacrifice every morning without fail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Sovereign Lord says: If the prince gives a gift of land to one of his sons as his inheritance, it will belong to him and his descendants forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the prince gives a gift of land from his inheritance to one of his servants, the servant may keep it only until the Year of Jubilee, which comes every fiftieth year. At that time the land will return to the prince. But when the prince gives gifts to his sons, those gifts will be permanent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the prince may never take anyone’s property by force. If he gives property to his sons, it must be from his own land, for I do not want any of my people unjustly evicted from their property.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In my vision, the man brought me through the entrance beside the gateway and led me to the sacred rooms assigned to the priests, which faced toward the north. He showed me a place at the extreme west end of these rooms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He explained, “This is where the priests will cook the meat from the guilt offerings and sin offerings and bake the flour from the grain offerings into bread. They will do it here to avoid carrying the sacrifices through the outer courtyard and endangering the people by transmitting holiness to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought me back to the outer courtyard and led me to each of its four corners. In each corner I saw an enclosure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of these enclosures was 70 feet long and 52 1⁄2 feet wide, surrounded by walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Along the inside of these walls was a ledge of stone with fireplaces under the ledge all the way around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man said to me, “These are the kitchens to be used by the Temple assistants to boil the sacrifices offered by the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In my vision, the man brought me back to the entrance of the Temple. There I saw a stream flowing east from beneath the door of the Temple and passing to the right of the altar on its south side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man brought me outside the wall through the north gateway and led me around to the eastern entrance. There I could see the water flowing out through the south side of the east gateway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Measuring as he went, he took me along the stream for 1,750 feet and then led me across. The water was up to my ankles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He measured off another 1,750 feet and led me across again. This time the water was up to my knees. After another 1,750 feet, it was up to my waist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he measured another 1,750 feet, and the river was too deep to walk across. It was deep enough to swim in, but too deep to walk through.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked me, “Have you been watching, son of man?” Then he led me back along the riverbank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I returned, I was surprised by the sight of many trees growing on both sides of the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to me, “This river flows east through the desert into the valley of the Dead Sea. The waters of this stream will make the salty waters of the Dead Sea fresh and pure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There will be swarms of living things wherever the water of this river flows. Fish will abound in the Dead Sea, for its waters will become fresh. Life will flourish wherever this water flows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fishermen will stand along the shores of the Dead Sea. All the way from En-gedi to En-eglaim, the shores will be covered with nets drying in the sun. Fish of every kind will fill the Dead Sea, just as they fill the Mediterranean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the marshes and swamps will not be purified; they will still be salty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fruit trees of all kinds will grow along both sides of the river. The leaves of these trees will never turn brown and fall, and there will always be fruit on their branches. There will be a new crop every month, for they are watered by the river flowing from the Temple. The fruit will be for food and the leaves for healing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Sovereign Lord says: “Divide the land in this way for the twelve tribes of Israel: The descendants of Joseph will be given two shares of land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Otherwise each tribe will receive an equal share. I took a solemn oath and swore that I would give this land to your ancestors, and it will now come to you as your possession.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These are the boundaries of the land: The northern border will run from the Mediterranean toward Hethlon, then on through Lebo-hamath to Zedad;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then it will run to Berothah and Sibraim, which are on the border between Damascus and Hamath, and finally to Hazer-hatticon, on the border of Hauran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the northern border will run from the Mediterranean to Hazar-enan, on the border between Hamath to the north and Damascus to the south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The eastern border starts at a point between Hauran and Damascus and runs south along the Jordan River between Israel and Gilead, past the Dead Sea and as far south as Tamar. This will be the eastern border.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The southern border will go west from Tamar to the waters of Meribah at Kadesh and then follow the course of the Brook of Egypt to the Mediterranean. This will be the southern border.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “On the west side, the Mediterranean itself will be your border from the southern border to the point where the northern border begins, opposite Lebo-hamath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Divide the land within these boundaries among the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Distribute the land as an allotment for yourselves and for the foreigners who have joined you and are raising their families among you. They will be like native-born Israelites to you and will receive an allotment among the tribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These foreigners are to be given land within the territory of the tribe with whom they now live. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here is the list of the tribes of Israel and the territory each is to receive. The territory of Dan is in the extreme north. Its boundary line follows the Hethlon road to Lebo-hamath and then runs on to Hazar-enan on the border of Damascus, with Hamath to the north. Dan’s territory extends all the way across the land of Israel from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Asher’s territory lies south of Dan’s and also extends from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Naphtali’s land lies south of Asher’s, also extending from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then comes Manasseh south of Naphtali, and its territory also extends from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: South of Manasseh is Ephraim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and then Reuben,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and then Judah, all of whose boundaries extend from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “South of Judah is the land set aside for a special purpose. It will be 8 1⁄3 miles wide and will extend as far east and west as the tribal territories, with the Temple at the center.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The area set aside for the Lord’s Temple will be 8 1⁄3 miles long and 6 2⁄3 miles wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the priests there will be a strip of land measuring 8 1⁄3 miles long by 3 1⁄3 miles wide, with the Lord’s Temple at the center.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This area is set aside for the ordained priests, the descendants of Zadok who served me faithfully and did not go astray with the people of Israel and the rest of the Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will be their special portion when the land is distributed, the most sacred land of all. Next to the priests’ territory will lie the land where the other Levites will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The land allotted to the Levites will be the same size and shape as that belonging to the priests—8 1⁄3 miles long and 3 1⁄3 miles wide. Together these portions of land will measure 8 1⁄3 miles long by 6 2⁄3 miles wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: None of this special land may ever be sold or traded or used by others, for it belongs to the Lord; it is set apart as holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “An additional strip of land 8 1⁄3 miles long by 1 2⁄3 miles wide, south of the sacred Temple area, will be allotted for public use—homes, pasturelands, and common lands, with a city at the center.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city will measure 1 1⁄2 miles on each side—north, south, east, and west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Open lands will surround the city for 150 yards in every direction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Outside the city there will be a farming area that stretches 3 1⁄3 miles to the east and 3 1⁄3 miles to the west along the border of the sacred area. This farmland will produce food for the people working in the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who come from the various tribes to work in the city may farm it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This entire area—including the sacred lands and the city—is a square that measures 8 1⁄3 miles on each side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The areas that remain, to the east and to the west of the sacred lands and the city, will belong to the prince. Each of these areas will be 8 1⁄3 miles wide, extending in opposite directions to the eastern and western borders of Israel, with the sacred lands and the sanctuary of the Temple in the center.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the prince’s land will include everything between the territories allotted to Judah and Benjamin, except for the areas set aside for the sacred lands and the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These are the territories allotted to the rest of the tribes. Benjamin’s territory lies just south of the prince’s lands, and it extends across the entire land of Israel from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: South of Benjamin’s territory lies that of Simeon, also extending across the land from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next is the territory of Issachar with the same eastern and western boundaries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then comes the territory of Zebulun, which also extends across the land from east to west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The territory of Gad is just south of Zebulun with the same borders to the east and west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The southern border of Gad runs from Tamar to the waters of Meribah at Kadesh and then follows the Brook of Egypt to the Mediterranean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These are the allotments that will be set aside for each tribe’s exclusive possession. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These will be the exits to the city: On the north wall, which is 1 1⁄2 miles long,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: there will be three gates, each one named after a tribe of Israel. The first will be named for Reuben, the second for Judah, and the third for Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the east wall, also 1 1⁄2 miles long, the gates will be named for Joseph, Benjamin, and Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The south wall, also 1 1⁄2 miles long, will have gates named for Simeon, Issachar, and Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And on the west wall, also 1 1⁄2 miles long, the gates will be named for Gad, Asher, and Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The distance around the entire city will be 6 miles. And from that day the name of the city will be ‘The Lord Is There.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator
